0375707972|5.0|This book is excellent!  It truly made me think and evaluate my own personal philosophy of the world and people.  You can't walk away from this book unchanged.
B000000OSE|2.0|first things first i'm not a hater of GNR s good band from the eighties not great i loved GNR lies the EP/album and i loved one of the greatest albums from the eighties appetite for destruction a classic but this is four years after destruction had been released and what is released a double album wow what an orignal thought like nobody else before has thought of that I.E the beatles, led zeppelin..   but no this is supposed to be a first part of a masterpiece   but really it just sounds like a 7 track single yes there's only   7 songs i like on this album..i know all you GNR fans will looked shocked only 7 they'll cry he must be stupid no i'm not stupid i just know when i hear quality i don't hear here very often only a few places i went wow this is great   and these are   dust n bones, live and let die the cover of a paul mccartney song not an orignal GNR creation,   don't cry,not the alternative because it's sucks and it features shannon hoon from blind melon on backing vocals  november rain although it's over the top it's still okay   garden of eden..for the head banging mosh   dead horse it's a classic   and coma for the ten minute wake up   after a listen to a bloated album from a good band
B00005JOHI|5.0|I am not worthy of writing a review of this film, but I MUST try.<br /><br />It seems like only yesterday Codemaster Talon (my genius sister and fellow Amazon reviewer) and myself were sitting in a darkened theater watching previews before some film or other, and saw a fleeting glimpse of yet another Jane Austin inspired film. That was my initial reaction, \\"Oh no, not ANOTHER one...\\". And yet, within that short time I was intrigued. The acting looking competent, and the cinematography absolutely breath-taking. \\"I'll see it for the cinematography alone,\\" I commented to my companion.<br /><br />Now I don't pretend to be half the Jane Austin fan that Codemaster Talon is. I don't pretend to be some kind of literary higher critic or the absolute authority on historical accuracy and proper period acting. I do however, know a good story when I see one. Pride and Prejudice as a story in all it's versions holds a very special place in my heart. You see at it's core it is the story of two very similar personality types who are monstrously incompatible on the surface, and perfect compliments deep down.<br /><br />Elizabeth Bennet is an introvert who acts the extrovert, a whimsical person who is practical deep down, a genius who cares more about her friends' happiness than impressing others, and wishes for true love more than riches. She's a young woman who uses her feelings to deal with the world but most treasures her intuition. Darcy is a person who has all his feelings buried deep down. He's an introvert who keeps to himself unless compelled to action. He's logical and analytical, but treasures his feelings above all. He's blunt with his feelings, because so few people understand them. He's arrogant and proud, but courageous, and noble. In short he's the exact opposite of Elizabeth in every way save one. They are both people who live in their own universe separate from the rest of the world. And they are both VERY stubborn and judgmental.<br /><br />I've seen the old version of this story with Sir Laurence Olivier as Darcy and Greer Garson as Elizabeth. I've seen the gold-standard A&E version which caused such an uproar with it's amazing dialog and acting. I have never seen anything like this. Never before has the true heart and soul of Liz and Darcy been on display. Never before could I see clearly expressed WHY  they fell in love with each other. In fact, never before could I see a real sign that they HAD fallen in love with each other. Now I see it.<br /><br />A movie is more than just acting with some music and sound effects tossed in, captured through a hand-held camera (despite what Indy film buffs may have told you). A real movie uses the acting to further the dialog, the dialog to further the action, the music to further the moment captured by the lens. Everything pushes  to express feelings and emotions that grab a hold of you and don't let go. I mentioned that the preview for this movie intrigued me because of the cinematography, but I had NO IDEA what was yet to come.<br /><br />Painting with Color, Drawing with Light<br /><br />The title of this movie appears in a ray of sunlight. The first few minutes take us inside of the Bennet house with a genius that reminded me of the camera-work of The Magnificent Ambersons' greatest shot. And it only gets better. This is not showy camera-work for it's own sake. Everything has a point in this movie. Those opening minutes told multiple stories at once. Those first time I saw this movie beginning made me think first of the  standing of the household (as the lived-in and somewhat decayed nature of the estate was quite apparent), then of the personality of the main character (carrying a book and inside her own world despite all the hustle and bustle around her), and then of the personality of everyone else inside the house, as each person's body language, voice and activity summarized their personality in a snapshot.<br /><br />As the film progressed I witnessed a country party quite unlike anything I've seen in a Jane Austin film before. The party was lively and ecstatic and looked like FUN. And when Darcy and his friend came to the party we could quite quickly see how everyone else was a country bumpkin compared to them (something that was never so clear to me before). More than that, again the use of camera angles and body language spoke beyond the dialog to hint at things unsaid. \\"Interesting,\\" I thought. \\"This movie is going to be interesting.\\" Then came the first scene where I honestly was mentally agasp with the question \\"How did they do that?\\". Liz and Jane are having a sister-to-sister conversation under the bed covers late at night and the perspective of the camera is the the arm of one sister, then it switches back to the other sister's perspective. \\"Where's the camera?\\", was all I could think. Not good camera use, GREAT.<br /><br />There were three moments in this film that  took my breath away (and while it was certainly impressive and added enormously to the picture, the dance between Darcy and Elizabeth where everyone else disappears {an effect executed marvelously here} is not one of them). The moments were these:<br /><br />The Proposal<br /><br />Firstly, Darcy's famous proposal. Normally portrayed somewhat arrogantly on Darcy's part, here it is played with passion, and we can see his heartache. Nay, we can FEEL his heartache. The whole scene happens in the rain, outdoors, with Liz and Darcy starting somewhat apart, and, as he proposes and she rejects him with more and more fury, they gradually get closer and closer until by the end of the scene their faces are nearly touching. I could FEEL the magnetism between the characters. I could SEE for the first time, that it was not HIM that she was rejecting (though she thought she was) but his ACTIONS. Despite her words, she was clearly drawn to him, absorbed in his personality. Though for so long she acted indifferent toward him, seemingly not caring, she was in fact almost obsessed with him. Yeah, I got all that from one scene.<br /><br />On top of the World<br /><br />Okay, this was it, the moment when I knew that I didn't just like this movie, I had fallen head-over-heels-in-love! While there are many splendid moments of wide-screen wide-angle shots (YES!), and some super-nice super-close-ups (the beauty is almost too much for my eyes!), this scene truly takes the cake. It starts with Lizzy in a carriage, the camera  on her eyes as sunlight and shadow dance across them. Then, the camera cuts to a STUNNING  shot of Elizabeth standing at the edge of a cliff with the wind blowing against her. The music swells and... GOODNESS. I'm glad I have ears and eyes and life within me to witness spectacles like this.<br /><br />Your Hands Are Cold.<br /><br />I've always loved Darcy as a character, for the same reason I loved Colonel Brandon in Sense and Sensibility. To me he's always been a hero, a great man just waiting for a chance to prove his strength and courage. This is perhaps the most powerful scene of the movie. After a terrible confrontation with the Lady Catherine, Lizzy gets up early in the cold morning and walks out into the hills. Just as the sun is coming up, who appears but Darcy, walking up with his jacket billowing in the wind like a hero's cape, sad, noble, and with depth of emotion to bring you to tears. It's like a hero coming back from a war. As he and Lizzy talk, they draw close together just as the sun is coming up between the two of them. That's what I live for. It's a moment that's so romantic and larger than life that it belongs alongside the greatest from Gone With the Wind and Casablanca. I don't know what else to say.<br /><br />The Film<br /><br />What can I say about the acting of this film? For the first time in ages I forgot I was watching ACTORS and felt like I was watching a story unfold in front of me. I haven't felt this way since I was a kid. I forgot anyone was acting. For the most part, the characters in the film simply WERE. In other words, I smell Academy Awards.<br /><br />Knightley's Elizabeth is sharp, sensitive, sweet, and strong, a fully fleshed out acting job that simply makes us believe she IS the character. Matthew Macfadyen's Darcy is so sincere, so from the heart, that we cannot for one moment doubt his sincerity. He brings new depth to a new interpretation of a classic character. Rosamund Pike's Jane is simply overflowing with sweetness and good nature (and the scene of her leaving to pursue her love in the back of a carriage is feminine beauty personified). Even the so often portrayed as unbearably oily Mr. Collins gets a new spin as played by Tom Hollander. I actually felt SORRY for the guy a few times (trapped as he is in his own ridiculous world and never realizing how absolutely pathetic and silly he seems). Also wonderfully done are the Bennet parents played by Brenda Blethyn and Donald Sutherland. Mrs. Bennet comes across more as a misunderstood sweet parent than a hyper-annoying flibbertigibbet. And Mr. Bennet just has more emotional resonance than in any previous version I've ever seen. Just about everyone is perfectly played in this movie.<br /><br />The music is sparing, but used to great effect. Never overwhelming the action, but rather pushing it, the soundtrack is quite good (I have it). There are moments of supreme beauty to be heard, but on the whole the soundtrack is rather sparse (comes to little more than half an hour).<br /><br />Some reviewers on the Net said that this production was by-the-numbers. I can understand that...if you happen to be color-blind, tone-deaf, and wouldn't know a good script if it smacked you upside the head. This film deserves to sweep the Oscars in every category. So perfect is the camera-work ( I have seen nothing like it since the days of Ford, Cardiff and Kurosawa), the score (heart-breaking), the acting (I love ALL the characters), and the script (it reaches straight into your heart) that EVERYONE should enjoy this film. Like the story that inspired it, it is a perfect marriage of the Male and Female personalities combining the Epic feel and strength of a man's film with the delicacy, beauty, and wit of a woman's film. I had thought long ago that the two great miracles of film-making would be to make the ordinary seem Epic, or the Epic seem ordinary. This film makes the ordinary, the lives and loves of people, into something as Epic as the end of the world or the blazing of new frontiers. I for one shall never be the same. After seeing this film I look at the world in a different way, and perhaps always shall.<br /><br />If this movie has one major flaw it is this: it is FAR too short at 2 hours. This is simply too big a story with too many characters to tell in that short a time. As such a lot of things things had to be spelled-out, and entire scenes and characters got the chopping block. And another reason I wish it were longer: I enjoyed every moment of this film so much I never wanted it to end.  My first words at as the end credits rolled were something like \\"I can't wait for the director's cut.\\" You could wait for it to come out on DVD, but then you'd have to buy a big-screen TV and a surround-sound system to experience it's full glory. And to see this one on pan-and-scan would be to cut it's head off with a guillotine. In short, THIS is the film that EVERYONE has been waiting for.<br /><br />I tried to write a review. I really did. Words failed me. Please see this film in the theater. Please.in fact almost obsessed with him. Yeah, I got all that from one scene. <br /> <br />On top of the World <br /> <br />Okay, this was it, the moment when I knew that I didn't just like this movie, I had fallen head-over-heels-in-love! While there are many splendid moments of wide-screen wide-angle shots (YES!), and some super-nice super-close-ups (the beauty is almost too much for my eyes!), this scene truly takes the cake. B000AL730O|4.0|All too often since the Beatles went their separate ways, Paul McCartney has failed to live up to expectations, the comparisons with Cole Porter; nearly half of his studio albums are, as the Brits like to say, rubbish. From time to time, however, he manages to rise above his penchant for slapdash recording sessions and &#34;silly love songs&#34; and make a good disc. &#34;Chaos and Creation in the Backyard&#34; is not only good, it's one of his best. Twenty-five years ago, the murder of ex-bandmate John Lennon spurred McCartney to new heights in his solo career, and George Harrison's recent death of cancer seems to have motivated him in much the same fashion.  &#34;Chaos&#34; is less upbeat than the typical McCartney record, its overall sound something of a departure for him. In fine voice throughout, he's also a one-man orchestra, playing guitar, drums, flugelhorn, cello, recorder, tubular bells, Moog and, most prominently, piano.  Highlights include &#34;Friends to Go,&#34; which pays homage to Harrison by imitating his style; the jaunty &#34;English Tea&#34;; &#34;A Certain Softness,&#34; a slinky romantic number in which McCartney uncharacteristically refrains from using the word &#34;love&#34;; &#34;Riding to Vanity Fair,&#34; which admonishes an acquaintance: &#34;And I was open to friendship/ But you didn't seem to have any to spare/ While you were riding to vanity fair&#34;; and the final, hidden track, an instrumental. &#34;Vanity Fair&#34; ranks with the pick of his solo work, songs such as &#34;Give Ireland Back to the Irish,&#34; &#34;Mrs. Vandebilt,&#34; &#34;Sally G,&#34; &#34;Rock Show,&#34; &#34;Daytime Nighttime Suffering,&#34; &#34;The Pound Is Sinking,&#34; &#34;Get It,&#34; &#34;Angry,&#34; &#34;This One&#34; and &#34;The World Tonight.&#34;  As good as &#34;Chaos&#34; is, 1982's &#34;Tug of War,&#34; inspired by Lennon and produced by &#34;the fifth Beatle,&#34; George Martin, remains Sir Paul's best album, his one true masterpiece. &#34;Chaos&#34; comes close but is marred by several cuts with vapid lyrics. &#34;Follow Me,&#34; for example, sounds as if it were composed expressly for the Fidelity Investments commercial in which it's featured.  The disc also suffers by comparison with the recent solo release from another rock legend, Stephen Stills, who began his career emulating the Fab Four. On &#34;Man Alive!&#34;, which has been given short shrift by the critics, Stills demonstrates a multi-instrumental virtuosity to rival McCartney's, command of a variety of genres -- rock, blues, jazz, Cajun and Latin music -- and a lyric-writing talent that the former Beatle can't match.

B00005JO1P|2.0|Hollywood has been making biopic (biographical) films since the beginning of films.  At first, the biographies were overly positive.  \\"The Pride of the Yankees\\", \\"The Charles Lindberg Story,\\" even the post WWII movie \\"The Desert Fox\\" focused more on the positive aspects of Erwin Rommel, a German Field Marshal.  Eventually the genre changed to try to provide a deeper understanding of the person.  \\"Lawrence of Arabia\\" is the classic example; in that movie the viewer was exposed not to just what T.E. Lawrence did, but who he was. <br /> <br />Eventually these biopic films became much more honest, incorporating both the positive and the negative aspects of individuals.  This is fine; I don't want propaganda in biopic films.  It's fascinating to see the darker side of important figures.  It makes them much more real, and yet makes their accomplishments all the more spectacular.  The movie \\"Ray\\" epitomizes this balance. <br /> <br />\\"Ray\\" was one of the best movies of the decade.  The story of Ray Charles put to the silver screen.  Audiences got a healthy dose of music, an incredible performance by Jamie Foxx, and a fair picture of the life of Ray Charles, including the low points and the high points. <br /> <br />\\"Walk the Line\\" should be the same thing as \\"Ray.\\"  It's a biography of a musical figure who had low points in his life.  But in execution, \\"Walk the Line\\" comes no where near the quality of \\"Ray.\\"  Even in the genre of biographies this movie fails to live up to any standard.  Even if it were decided that Walk the Line should not be compared to \\"Ray,\\" it's still my conclusion that this film isn't worth the price of any admission. <br /> <br />Joaquin Phoenix does a good job portraying the enigmatic singer Johnny Cash; Reese Witherspoon shows her abilities playing the part of June Carter.  The movie looks good, each scene has good direction.  But this movie lacks any kind of spirit.  It has an almost flat reception.  In fact, a major part of the story, the romance between June Carter and Johnny Cash, is absent.  There is no chemistry.  It's not a love story at all.  Carter and Cash appear only as close friends. <br /> <br />The film focuses on ten years of Cash's life.  Ten dark years where Cash was ruled by an addiction to amphetamines and other drugs.  Ten years of strife with his first wife.  Ten years of adultery.  The movie hardly does justice to the life of Johnny Cash, it focuses more on the faults of Johnny Cash.  The goal of this movie was to destroy the memory of Johnny Cash.  It did not present a balanced view of the man's life.  It did not tell us of his origins.  There are few epiphanies.  The characters don't grow as people.  Cash is not presented as a deep character.  He's more or less portrayed as an antagonist. <br /> <br />The man who was Johnny Cash is not present in this film.  The film does not portray his recovery from drugs.  In an act of pure \\"Christo-phobia\\" the movie fails to show Johnny Cash answering an alter-call.  The movie was designed to destroy the man.  Cash's humanly faults become the movie, and the movie exaggerates those faults.  After watching \\"Ray\\" I had a better understanding, respect and empathy for Ray Charles. This movie leaves me no such feelings for Johnny Cash.  It fails as a biography, and it fails as a film.  It belongs to the \\"Made for TV\\" movie genre, not the silver screen.  Save your Cash and go elsewhere. <br />
B000929AJQ|4.0|A lot of people have been calling With Teeth different in a bad way.  I'll agree with the first part, but people need to look beyond the musical spectrum that, in itself, is Nine Inch Nails.  Was Pretty Hate Machine any different from Ministry's Effigy, or any Wumpscut album?  Was the Broken EP any different from a synthesized version of the grungy early 90's?  The Fragile was a jazzy record with a little more emphasis on the lighter tones and music of Nine Inch Nails.  Can any Nine Inch Nail record be called entirely original?  No.  Trent Reznor takes music fashion and adds a dark twist that I, and millions of others, enjoy.  The music of With Teeth is in a nu-metalish order with a little of Trent's signature on it.  The synth in All the Love in the World is reflective of his piano stylings, but also highly reminiscent of most rock effigies.  The drum part for You Know What You Are is original, but the music, lyrics, and production is pure derivative.  Please, NIN fans, be a little more accepting and try to see my point of view.  This album is contrast, not crap.

B00005JOHI|4.0|Joe Wright was cast to direct the latest version of \\"Pride and Prejudice\\". Hmmmm. Joe Wright, directed a couple of forgettable movies, followed by 3 mini-series (the little knowns \\"Nature Boy\\" from 2000, \\"Bodily Harm\\" from 2002 and a lavish, and well-made version of the life of Charles 2,\\"Charles II: The Power and the Passion, 2003) for A&E/BBC. What made the powers behind the newest attempt to film Austen for the big screen choose Joe Wright?<br /><br />Well, Joe got it, right, that is, in many ways. He's made a more contemporary telling of this, my favorite of Austen's tales, and he's done it well. In a run time of less than 2.5 hours, his version will be more easier to digest than the two mini-series of this same work (the stand alone BBC version from 1980 with Elizabeth Garvie and David Rintoul and the 1993 A&E/BBC version that most people know the best; with Jennifer Ehle and Colin Firth). But, as well done as it is, you'll find it wanting vs. either of these fine mini-series, and the film also pales in comparison to the Emma Thompson/Ang Lee run at \\"Sense and Sensibility\\" in 1995.<br /><br />If you are an Austen fan, the amount of characterization that has to be cut from the story to fit it in to a 2.5 hour run time, will simply horrify you. In particular, both Mr. Wickam and Mr. Collins, potential suitors for the Bennett bevy, are given very small amounts of screen time. Catherine de Bourg, the patroness whose money flows all over a variety of characters in the film (Darcy, for one, is her nephew) was played by Judi Dench with a particularly elegant stiff upper lip, but was given little to do.<br /><br />Director Wright has given us marvelous cinematography and beautiful settings (notably Darcy's estate at Pemberley). He has the same passion I do for Austen's work, and tried to keep the themes.<br /><br />\\"Pride and Prejudice\\" is a love story between a young woman in a family stretched with 5 daughters and literally no dowries in 19th century England. In the book, the Bennetts are an upper middle class lot; in this film, in which Wright instilled a sense of real \\"living on the farm\\", they are shabby versions of Austen's intent.<br /><br />Mr. Bennett (Donald Sutherland) is a country gentleman beloved by his daughters and befuddled by the antics of his wife. Said wife's main passion in life is making sure the girls are all married off so that they are not penniless when the parents die. Mrs. Bennett (Brenda Blethyn in a comedic performance that is perhaps a little over the top) makes no pretense of her intentions, and they are embraced with different degrees of exhuberance by her daughters. Elizabeth (Keira Knightley) and Jane (Rosamund Pike), the eldest, are a bit embarrassed by their mother's antics and manage to try and ignore her histrionics while building their anxieties over marriage.<br /><br />It is Jane, the loveliest, whose heart is broken by Mr. Bingley from London, and Elizabeth who runs afoul of his dour friend, Mr. Darcy.<br /><br />Before the film is finished, the viewer is as surprised as Elizabeth to learn that Mr. Darcy has fallen in love with her, and having been rejected, Darcy sets out to change Elizabeth's first impression and win her heart by helping her family and by showing how much he cares for his own young sister.<br /><br />Keira Knightley was a good choice for Jane, although the lesser known actresses in both the British mini-series were better in the role than she was. Knightley looks the part as Austen described it, and has a quicksilver screen persona that fits Elizabeth well. If there is not the romance, the chemistry that should have grown on screen between Elizabeth and Darcy, it is not for wont of Knightley's efforts to portray it.<br /><br />Instead, in portraying the difficult Darcy, who, after all, is supposed to be wooden, actor Matthew Macfayden (with an impressive list of British television credentials including the MI5 drama, Spooks) was entirely too successful. He is wooden toa painful degree, and has difficulty turning his cold arrogance into foolishness when he first becomes infatuated with Elizabeth. And he's equally not credible as a \\"do gooder\\". The growth of that Austen staple, the love between two people who society has not meant to be together, the growing awareness, the yearning, well, it is missing from this film. It was not missing in the mini-series. Generally speaking, it usually means the director does not know how to capture the essence of love and longing on film, does not know how to invoke it from his characters and bleed it through to the audience. Despite this, I must say, that I did not walk away wishing to see Matthew Macfayden on the big screen again.<br /><br />And thus, we get an interesting movie, with some fine touches, some believable characters, a solid script and beautiful filming, music and costumes. But contrary to the print ads and the trailers, this is not the film of the year, just a pleasing version of an Austen tale that has been done better in the past.<br /><br />Definitely worth a trip to the theater!successful. B0000025DT|5.0|From the Electric Light Orchestra's inception from the ashes of the Move in 1970, bandleader Jeff Lynne's aim was to continue on the trail the Beatles had blazed, crafting pristine melodic pop against a backdrop of classical grandiloquence. Lofty ambitions, even for a talent of Mr. Lynne's magnitude. But on 1976's A New World Record ELO got as close as anybody ever has to picking up where the Fab Four left off - and that's the highest praise you can give them.    On this, their sixth LP, ELO refined the increasingly commercial sound of Eldorado (1974) and Face the Music (1975) into a polished, super-accessible hit machine. Their recipe for success went something like this: A) Create an exciting, instantly memorable melody that would do the likes of Paul McCartney himself proud. B) Put lyrics to it and perform with bassist Kelly Groucutt's and drummer Bev Bevan's solid foundation, keyboardist Richard Tandy's spacey synthesizers, and Jeff Lynne's fluid guitar work and spine-tingling falsetto. C) Frost it with coat upon lustrous coat of fluttery vocal harmonies, overdubbed guitars and synths, and bombastic orchestral flourishes. D) Bake for 1 hour at 400 F, let cool for 10 minutes, and enjoy.      This ingenious formula forms the groundwork upon which A New World Record is constructed. Not surprisingly, it produced three huge singles - the adrenaline-charged Do Ya, dynamic Livin' Thing, and crushingly bittersweet Telephone Line - but every last cut here could've been a hit. Don't be fooled into believing this stuff is formulaic or uninspired, however. Jeff Lynne, who wrote and arranged it all, is as imaginative as he is ambitious. His most impressive achievement is the fact that, despite its prominence, he doesn't allow the orchestra to overwhelm the songs. Rather, true to his aspirations, he turns it into an absolutely integral part of the whole. In doing so he makes Rockaria's overwrought blues-meets-opera sound almost effortless, lends the quasi-symphonic pretensions of Tightrope a sense of authenticity, and elevates the stunning closer Shangri-La to positively epic proportions, not to mention the rest. Quite an accomplishment, made all the more astonishing by the fact it could've gone so wrong.    Granted, A New World Record was a product of its time - feathery falsettos; quasi-prog showboating; string-laden (what some might call) overproduction; and an irresistable, state-of-the-70s commercial aesthetic. But if it's to be taken as any indication, them's was the best of times...
B000BO0LLS|5.0|For the last 15 years all it took was one high note to recognize the undeniable voice of the biggest selling female artist of the 90's, Mariah Carey.  Critics and fans alike, though amazed by Carey's vocal range were missing the belting soul driven shy girl that sang songs such as \\"Vision of Love\\" and performed full power on MTV's Unplugged series.  Earlier this year radio was treated to a delightful surprise, the Mariah Carey that we have come to expect had evolved and started off her first single with a confident party starter, \\"It's Like That\\" instead of the light vocals and ode to a guy she cannot have, Carey declared it's her night and she'd have it no other way.  It's more like her year, 2005 has been great to Carey, with the release of \\"The Emancipation of Mimi\\" earlier in April she delighted music fans by using her incredible vocal range once again, experimenting with different producers (Kanye West, Jim Wright, Jermaine Dupri, Neptunes)to give her a trademark sound with a bit of Mariah that not even her fans were used to.  The album has gone on to sell 4 million copies in the States alone and has produced her biggest record to date, \\"We Belong Together\\" along with Radio hits \\"Shake It Off\\" and the current \\"Don't Forget About Us.\\"  The latter is off the recently re-issued package known as the \\"Ultra Platinum Edition.\\"  The cd comes with new artwork and 3 new tracks, including the remix to \\"We Belong Together\\" featuring Jadakiss and Styles P.  \\"Don't Forget About Us\\" is not much of a departure from \\"We Belong Together\\" and its signature style, but radio isn't complaining, it has a confidence in vocals and track and the video is just as provacative, if not more.  The second recording with Twista is known as \\"So Lonely (One & Only Pt. II)\\" and is a different take than the one found on Twista's album, as this one features Carey starting off the track with her own rhymes.  The track, produced by Darkchild, has monster hit written all over its smooth, bass driven,seductive chorus and playful words.  Mariah teamed up with J.D. once again for the new track, \\"Makin' It Last All Nite (What It Do)\\" and she sings Shai's lyrics in a teasing tone with Jermaine making a guest appearance on the track.  The album flows from start to finish, picks up with party tracks, uptempo tracks that get the younger and older audiences ready for their own nights, but brings us back to why we fell in love with \\"THE VOICE\\" to begin with on tracks your average singer would dare not tackle, such as the Glady's Knight styled \\"Circles\\", one of the best tracks on the album, with a full belting Carey singing \\"Stay The Night\\", \\"Your Girl\\", \\"I Wish You Knew\\" and the powerful \\"Mine Again.\\"  With the repackaging, the once almost flawless album steps into a realm of perfection that artists only dream of having.   <br /> <br />Keep an eye out for the limited CD/DVD combo, as the interview \\"Mariah In Her Own Words\\" is worth buying the album all on its own, with hilarious outtakes and \\"diva behind the scenes\\" moments along with all 5 videos. (\\"Get Your Number\\" only released overseas, \\"Don't Forget About Us\\" available with WebLink) <br /> <br />
B00005JNQS|3.0|When you throw together a decent plot formula, high quality slick animation, Blue Man Group on music, a fine stable of voice actors, and, well, probably tons of funds, I'd expect to see a very entertaining movie. And while Robots is certainly entertaining, it never ratchets itself up into the land of four stars. <br /> <br />The natural comparison is Monsters, Inc., which I still pull out every so often (more often now that I have an 18 month old daughter). Sections of Robots are filled with the same sorts of allusions that generate an chuckle at the cleverness of the creators. That cleverness, however, overloads the movie, and feels too intentional (\\"Wouldn't it be clever if we...\\"), instead of giving additional levels of amusement. <br /> <br />The cast of characters is, also, I think a bit too large for total enjoyment on a first viewing, as I was too busy trying to keep track of people, not knowing how significant they were going to be. <br /> <br />And all that, the cleverness and the number of characters, and the clear amount of thought and energy that went into this makes me think I'm going to watch it again, and probably even enjoy it more the second time around. <br /> <br />Maybe I should have given it four stars after all.

If that's what you're looking for, I fully endorse Brown--although I'd start with \\"Angels and Demons,\\" which is his best novel to date. B00005QGAV|5.0|Despite the success of Bad, it was hard not to view it as a bit of a letdown, since it presented a cleaner, colder, calculated version of Thriller -- something that delivered what it should on the surface, but wound up offering less in the long run. So, it was time for a change-up, something even a superstar as huge as Michael Jackson realized, so he left Quincy Jones behind, hired Guy mastermind Teddy Riley as the main producer, and worked with a variety of other producers, arrangers, and writers, most notably Bruce Swedien and Bill Bottrell. The end result of this is a much sharper, harder, riskier album than Bad, one that has its eyes on the street, even if its heart gets middle-class soft on \\"Heal the World.\\" The shift in direction and change of collaborators has liberated Jackson, and he's written a set of songs that is considerably stronger than Bad, often approaching the consistency of Off the Wall and Thriller. If it is hardly as effervescent or joyous as either of those records, chalk it up to his suffocating stardom, which results in a set of songs without much real emotional center, either in their substance or performance. But, there's a lot to be said for professional craftsmanship at its peak, and Dangerous has plenty of that, not just on such fine singles as \\"In the Closet,\\" \\"Remember the Time,\\" or the blistering \\"Jam,\\" but on album tracks like \\"Why You Wanna Trip on Me.\\" No, it's not perfect -- it has a terrible cover, a couple of slow spots, and suffers from CD-era ailments of the early '90s, such as its overly long running time and its deadening Q Sound production, which sounds like somebody forgot to take the Surround Sound button off. Even so, Dangerous captures Jackson at a near-peak, delivering an album that would have ruled the pop charts surely and smoothly if it had arrived just a year earlier. But it didn't -- it arrived along with grunge, which changed the rules of the game nearly as much as Thriller itself. Consequently, it's the rare multi-platinum, number one album that qualifies as a nearly forgotten, underappreciated record. [In 2001, a remastered edition was released with a detailed booklet]
B000AYQLX6|5.0|Most critics seem to agree that \\"Walls and Bridges\\" is Lennon's second weakest album, right after \\"Sometime In New York City.\\" It's been criticized as being unfocused and having filler. Although most critics will grant that the album does have some redeeming qualities and a few good songs. I strongly disagree with what most critics say about this album. In my opinion, \\"Wall and Bridges\\" stands alongside \\"Plastic Ono Band,\\" and \\"Imagine\\" as being some of the best music Lennon ever recorded. I would even put \\"Walls and Bridges\\" right alongside Led Zeppelin's \\"Zoso\\" and Pink Floyd's \\"Dark Side of the Moon\\" as one of the best albums of the 1970s.<br /><br />John Lennon's music has often been autobiographical. This album shows that as much as any other album he recorded. At the time, Lennon was a man in pain. He was separated from Yoko and unsure of what to do or where he wanted to go. He indulged in drinking and heavy partying in the infamous \\"Lost Weekend.\\" This album is not a catharsis of raw emotion like \\"The Plastic Ono Band.\\" This album is more like a diary from a dark period in a mans life. It's not so much a cry for help, but more of an album of resignation and defeat.<br /><br />The album opens with \\"Down On Love\\" a mid-tempo song about falling to pieces. In his delivery, Lennon sounds as though he is pleading for help, but he also sounds dejected. \\"Whatever Get You Through the Night\\" is one of Lennon's biggest solo hits. A great catchy duet with Elton John. \\"Old Dirt Road\\" is a beautiful balled about being lost. \\"What you Got\\" is not one of the album's strongest tracks. It's just a sort of sloppy rocker, but it adds to the album's overall charm. \\"Bless You\\" another beautiful balled in the vein of \\"Imagine.\\" \\"Scared\\" is a cool mid-tempo song whose meaning is self-explanatory. But in his singing, the song sounds as though Lennon really is scared--it sounds lived in. When he's yelling that he's scared, you can feel the mans torment. \\"Scared\\" runs perfectly into \\"#-9 Dream\\" a lush, pop-savvy mid-tempo rocker with cool cellos. \\"Surprise, Surprise (Sweet Bird of Paradise)\\" is another filler song--not great, not bad--just filler. The album would have been slightly better without its inclusion. \\"Steel and Glass\\" is the follow-up to \\"How Do You Sleep at Night.\\" The contrast of it's raw, angry delivery with the lush music sounds great and enhances the song. \\"Beef Jerky\\" is a cool jam instrumental. \\"Nobody Loves You (When Your Down and Out)\\" is a depressing song about looking at life straight in the eye when you are lonely and dejected. \\"Ya Ya\\" is a filler sound byte, with Lennon's son, Julian on drums. It's a cool way to end the album.<br /><br />The original CD pressing sounded a bit stuffy. The new remastered edition is a big improvement.sh, pop-savvy mid-tempo rocker with cool cellos. \\"Surprise, Surprise (Sweet Bird of Paradise)\\" is another filler song--not great, not bad--just filler. The album would have been slightly better without its inclusion. \\"Steel and Glass\\" is the follow-up to \\"How Do You Sleep at Night.\\" The contrast of it's raw, angry delivery with the lush music sounds great and enhances the song. \\"Beef Jerky\\" is a cool jam instrumental. \\"Nobody Loves You (When Your Down and Out)\\" is a depressing song about looking at life straight in the eye when you are lonely and dejected. \\"Ya Ya\\" is a filler sound byte, with Lennon's son, Julian on drums. It's a cool way to end the album.     The original CD pressing sounded a bit stuffy. The new remastered edition is a big improvement.

B000AGTPUK|5.0|Tom Hanks and Robert Zemeckis, the same team who brought us such great movies as \\"Forrest Gump\\" and \\"Cast Away\\", have teamed up again, and they deliver perhaps their best movie ever in this classic adaptation of the popular children's book. <br /> <br />On Christmas Eve, a massive steam train suddenly appears in front of a boy's home.  The conductor, one of Hanks' many roles in the film, jumps off and asks if the boy is getting on.  The boy asks where the train is going.  \\"To the North Pole!\\" is the conductor's reply.  After thinking it over, the boy gets on the train and he, along with several other children are soon on their way to the North Pole to see Santa.  We are introduced to some other children along the way; a young African-American girl, a Know-It-All boy, and a shy boy.  During the course of the film, all of them become very good friends.   <br /> <br />As the train makes its way north, the viewer is treated to many breathtaking special effects.  The scenes where the train is going up and down the mountain passes and sliding over the frozen lake are true high points of the film.  I've never seen special effects this eye-popping before in an animated film.  They are simply superb.  Upon reaching the North Pole, the children are informed that one of them will receive the first gift of Christmas.  However, before this can happen, the children must overcome having their car come uncoupled from the rest of the train, and sliding down a long slide and ending up in Santa's bag.  Who will Santa choose to recieve the first Christmas gift? <br /> <br />Having three small children, I've seen my share of animated children's films in the last few years, but none of those even come close to this tremendous film.  The story is very touching, and the visual effects are out of this world.  I'm a huge Tom Hanks fan and I watch his movies every chance I get.  His roles in this movie are some of his very best, but his role as the wise and caring conductor is perhaps his best.  Needless to say, I give this movie my highest recommendation.  As long as you can still hear the sleighbell jingle, then you'll always be a true believer.

B0000TB01Y|5.0|\\"Wicked\\" suffers from being tugged every \\"witch\\" way by its great shortcomings and stellar successes. Though \\"suffer\\" is hardly an appropriate verb since \\"Wicked\\" has spent the past two years as the hottest ticket on Broadway and, I admit, deservingly so.    Winnie Holzman's book is smart and tender, and absolutely robbed of the Tony.  One wishes more were preserved on this disc.  Stephen Schwartz' score is absolutely scintillating, albeit in a way that relies heavily on \\"money notes\\" and orchestrations that captivate you by force.  For what it cares to achieve, it does well. The lyrics aren't as sophisticated as Holzman's book, but they suffice.     Stars Idina Menzel and Kristin Chenoweth both give Tony-demanding turns here (it's a shame they had to compete, not only with each other, but with Tonya Pinkins and Donna Murphy - all of whom deserved trophies).  Menzel claims her Tony loud and clear with her giddily hopeful \\"The Wizard and I\\" and, of course, \\"Defying Gravity\\" - the now-anthem of every fourteen year-old girl in the country.  She even manages to make the most of the dull \\"I'm Not That Girl\\".  Chenoweth's crystalline opera-trained voice shines in \\"No One Mourns the Wicked\\" and she's a scream in her diva solo, \\"Popular\\".  Her voice mixes well with Menzel's in the 11 o'clock \\"For Good\\".  It's shame she gets saddled with such embarrassingly obvious lyrics in \\"Thank Goodness\\".      Co-star Norbert Leo Butz sings well enough here, though ill-suited for the role. Carole Shelley is all-but-absent here on disc and THAT is a crying shame. Joel Grey is in fine form, though criminally underused.      Still, \\"Wicked\\" is something special. In a time when Broadway is largely unimaginative garbarge, the sheer joy and magic of this musical make up for any technical shortcomings it may have. Is \\"Wicked\\" the greatest score to grace Broadway?  No. Do we care? No.

0441012906|5.0|My first surprise on reading this novel was that it isn't connected to any of Reynolds' earlier works. I then came to realise that the author has taken some standard SF components and refashioned them into something really really good.  <br /> <br />You have a disaster - \\"the Nanocaust\\" - that has wiped out all life on earth and left the remnants of humanity surviving in various places around the solar system. You have a form of faster than light travel that seems as grittily convincing as anything I've read. Above all, you have a massive structure that rivals Niven's Ringworld , Baxter's Ring and Shaw's Orbitsville for sheer mystery and has something really peculiar inside. <br /> <br />The two main characters are well-drawn and believable. Wendell Floyd is an American jazz musician and private detective who lives in 1950s Paris. Verity Auger is an archaeologist for the United States of Near Earth who is diverted from her exploration of barren, unhabitable Paris on to a mission to a very strange part of the galaxy indeed. They are going to meet up and find themselves solving a mystery , fighting revolting little soldiers , fleeing corrupt French policemen and trying to stop a monstrous crime. <br /> <br />I found the book easy to read - a bit easier than some of Reynolds earlier work. I was afraid the ending would be a bit of an anti-climax - but I was pleasantly surprised. <br /> <br />All in all, it's a great book, Go and buy it!

B0002EXH4A|4.0|I've bought this album recently, having not heard it in more than 15 years.  I have the original version, not the remix/remaster.  I think this is a great 80s speed metal album, a companion to Peace Sells... Megadeth would release their masterpiece, Rust in Peace, in 1990.  As some have mentioned, the production of So Far, So Good is rather outdated.  Or, rather, Michael Wagener's mix is outdated.  The snare drum on Mary Jane is unbearable; dead center, trebly, reverb madness, shrill.  Painful.  The second half of the record fairs better in that regard.  Regardless of this, if you can get used to the 80s mix, this is very satisfying material.  As my title says, Mustaine made his best music while high.  As far as I'm concerned, after Countdown to Extinction, Megadeth became redundant.  And, by the way, I love their cover here of Anarchy; I'll risk blasphemy and say more than the original!      I don't have any of the remix/remasters.  If they were only remasters (and good ones), I'd have those.  Sure, the remix strips out all of the reverb, but to me it sounds more generic. I listened to these records at the time, and this is how they were.  To me, the reissues are like the Star Wars Special Edition. A bigger problem is the remastering; it's pushed beyond the limits of acceptable volume.  Everything, and I mean everything, is clipped to heck.  Zero dynamic range; just loud and louder, and the sound quality gets distorted.  Terrible.  This is plaguing hard rock/metal recordings and remasters.  No thanks.
B000BM6AVA|5.0|First I'd like to say that even though Daron Malakian isn't the best singer ever, his high pitched voice adds alot to the music on this album. Now, on to rating each track. <br /> <br />1. Attack - 3/5 - This song kind of suprised me when I first popped it into my computer. It seemed different. But once I got to the chorus, it was definatelly remeniscient of the first album. But all in all, it seemed a bit akward. <br /> <br />2. Dreaming - 4/5 - This is a fine song by system. It has alot of technical guitar and they use back up vocals really well. It goes from a fast paced verse to a nice, melodic chorus. It also takes a nice break with some pretty clean guitar riffs. All in all, this is a very well written song, and I found it to be extremely addicting. <br /> <br />3. Kill Rock N Roll - 3.5/5 - I had heard this song in concert when I saw SOAD, and I'd heard a recorded version from a concert about 4 months ago, and the cd version just doesn't do this song justice. They tend to play it a little bit faster in concert, and it sounds amazing. But the cd version has some nice effects w/ the guitar and such. It has some amusing lyrics as well. All in all, it's a fun song to listen to, but if the verses were sped up a bit it'd be just that much better. <br /> <br />4. Hypnotize - 3.5/5 - I've been listening to this song for about 2 weeks before the cd was released, and i have to say it made me pretty impressed, but it just doesn't compare to most of the songs on the album. The lyrics are nice, though, and are a major redeeming factor of the song.  <br /> <br />5. Stealing Society - 4/5 - This is another song of soad's that reminds me of their first album. Some fast guitar, pretty crazy lyrics, and it's a really energetic song. Being a guitarist myself, the guitar in this song is pretty complicated, yet it still flows really well. <br /> <br />6. Tentative - 5/5 - This was my favorite song on the album at first, and it definatelly seemed like one of the songs they'd put more work into. The lyrics are great, and extremely meaningfull. I found myself listening to this song over and over again before listening to the rest of the album, I thought it was that good. After about 2 minutes, the song seems really hypnotic with the melodic, high pitched voacals. Overall, this is one of my favorite songs on the album. <br /> <br />7. U-Fig - 3.5/5 - The title of this song was pretty intriguing, as was the begining. It jumped from slow paced guitar with some cymbals to a loud, fast paced, guitar driven song. Again, the lyrics of this song are outstanding, reflecting current times very well. <br /> <br />8. Holy Mountains - 4/5 - This is another song I heard in concert and I had heard a recorded version from a concert as well, so I was looking foward to the cd version. I was not dissapointed. It is another very hypnotic song, and the backing orchestral instruments along with the voice and guitar effects make for a very haunting song. <br /> <br />9. Vicinity of Obscenity - 5/5 - This was another song that caught my attention. It reminded me alot of the songs sugar and Chic N' Stu. Odd guitar riffs coupled with extremely odd lyrics make for a very interesting song. The Slower part is really amusing as well, a nice change. It was very flowing and sounded nice, besides the lyrics, which were a bit odd. But again, this was a very good track, a definate favorite of diehard SOAD fans. <br /> <br />10. Shes Like Herion - 5.5/5 - This song absolutely blew me away when I first heard it. The lyrics are truthful and packed with feeling. After about a minute thirty seconds, it gets really good. The choruses that follow have added emphasis on them, and it makes for a very powerful song. The end is nice too, when it slows down and Daron slowly says the chorus. Overall an awesome song. <br /> <br />11. Lonely Day - 4.5/5 - This song reminded me of Mr. Jack from Steal This Album. It is a slow, melodic song. After about a minute, Daron plays a guitar riff that is directly in harmony to his voice, and it sounds really good. This song demonstrates Systems matureness, even though it seems kind of corny. The guitar work in the solo and the end chorus are extremely well done. This is another song that I listened to a few times before moving on. <br /> <br />12. Soldier Side - 7/5 - This is BY FAR my favorite song on the entire cd. System saved the best for last. This is one of the most powerful songs I've heard recently, and it's alot better than the crap on the radio now. Touching on the War in Iraq and even religion, this song is amazing on so many levels. The guitar work is probably the best on the album. It's powerful, yet addictive; it tells a story with the lyrics, and it tells it well. I could definatelly see this song being a popular radio release. In my opinion, this is one of System's best works to date, right up there with some of the releases from previous cd's. <br /> <br />Overall on the cd - 4.5/5 - This Cd definatelly shows System's maturity as a band. They touch on all the popular topics of current times, and in a more adult manner than ever before. But don't let that decieve you, SOAD has been one of the bands that has barely changed since their first Cd. This would be a very good cd for the die hard System fans, and it is very much like their first release. The artwork on this album is amazing as well. I've always been a fan of abstract art, and this Cd strikes me as a vrey well thought out cd, and the artwork goes well with the overall theme of the Cd. I HIGHLY recomend this cd to System fan, new and old. You won't be dissapointed.

B00005JOHI|5.0|Like most people who love literature I was well aware that Jane Austen could write, but the idea that Keira Knightley can act and hold her own against the likes of Dame Judy Dench was a revelation.  Granted, Knightley has not particularly been called upon to turn in great acting performances in most of her films.  In \\"Love Actually\\" she is basically required to look pretty and her best moments are reaction shots rather than dialogue.  She has many more moments such as that in \\"Pride & Prejudice,\\" but she also proves herself proficient at the witty dialogue.  Knightley filmed this version as her final film as a teenager and the results are comparable to when Franco Zeffirelli cast the teenage Olivia de Hussey in \\"Romeo & Juliet.\\"<br /><br />This becomes the most romantic version of \\"Pride & Prejudice\\" because we are not surprised along with Lizzie when Mr. Darcy (Matthew MacFadyen) shows up and makes the most backhanded proposal of marriage in the history of Western literature.  The screenplay by Deborah Moggach (Emma Thompson receives special thanks in the credits, apparently for script doctoring) makes one significant change in the proceedings by simply having the moment when Darcy falls for Lizzie clearly written on his face.  At the Meryton ball she finds the perfect moment to throw the callous words that she has overheard back into his and with the rapier still skewering her victim she turns on her heels and walks away in triumph.<br /><br />When next he sees her she has walked over to Mr. Bingley's house to care for her sister Jane (Rosamund Pike), who has been taken ill because of the matrimonial machinations of their mother.  Lizzie's hair is down and she is positively glowing.  When we see the look of Darcy's face it is clear that he is beyond smitten, even though through the veneer of upper class manners the signs are decidedly subtle.  From that moment on his affection becomes transparent to us, although Lizzie is surprised to learn of its existence.  Joe Wright also creates a motif where the first time Darcy and Lizzie touch, as he helps her into a carriage, resonates by an emphasis at key moments throughout the film of Darcy's hands.<br /><br />Elizabeth Bennet is the most delightful of the Austen heroines because she has the virtue of not backing down.  Indeed, I believe Darcy first takes real notice of her because she stands up to him at the ball.  When she refuses to back down from Lady Catherine De Bourgh (Judi Dench) at the dinner table it struck me that one of the reasons she is so attractive to Darcy is because she is not trying to be.  Certainly Mrs. Bennet (Brenda Blythen) has taught her five daughters it is how to be on their best behavior to catch a husband, and in a world of such propriety her candor is refreshing.  Darcy's curt dismissal of her looks as being tolerable, but not handsome enough to tempt him, becomes ironic because for my money it is her brains that make Elizabeth Bennett a real beauty both to him and to us.<br /><br />The screenplay necessitates cutting much of the action to reduce the tale to a two-hour film.  I appreciated being spared the unfortunate incident of Mary at the pianoforte as well as the constructed scene for the final fadeout and my only minor complaint would be that Lady Catherine does not utter her exit line from the novel when she takes her leave of Elizabeth in their final confrontation although I fully understand that the words cannot be uttered under those circumstances and the fact that Lady Catherine shows up immediately on hearing the rumor makes up for being denied the pleasure of hearing Dame Judy declaim that line.<br /><br />I had heard that the Jane Austen Society was less than pleased by Knightley's posture in this film, but one of the strengths of this production is that the Bennetts clearly live in the country.  There are dirt roads that lead to their home, where a large hog wanders through the front door, and when Mr. Darcy and the Bingleys make their first appearances at the local ball the dancing has an exuberance (not to mention slapping of hands) that makes it patently clear that we are far from the hallowed halls of Pemberly or the civilized life of London.  But the outside locations are as sumptuous as the gilded rooms in this film, and cinematographer Roman Osin makes both look gorgeous.<br /><br />For those who consider \\"Sense & Sensibility\\" to be the current cinematic benchmark for Austen adaptations I can report that \\"Pride & Prejudice\\" is its superior in terms of both romance and comedy by virtue of both crying and laughing more at this 2005 film..  Where Ang Lee's 1995 film comes out ahead is in its depiction of sisterhood, as Jane and Lizzie cannot rival Elinor and Marianne in their bonds of affection, which is understandable since it is more central to that Austen novel.  Even so there is a cute moment of confidences shared beneath the covers and Lizzie's spirited defense of her sister's shyness.  However, this one really is all about Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy.<br /><br />I will not be surprised if Knightley receives a Best Actress nomination for her performance here (I still think Joan Allen is the front runner for \\"The Upside of Anger\\").  As is invariably the case with such films the cast of supporting players is superb.  Brenda Blethyn's Mrs. Bennet is the other clear Oscar contender, but Donald Sutherland as Mr. Bennet has a touching final scene with his daughter, Tom Hollander is toadally obnoxious as Mr. Collins, and my wife really wants to slap Jenna Malone's Lydia a couple of times.  We all know that this is the time of year when most of the films that will be up for Best Picture are released, and \\"Pride & Prejudice\\" has to be in the running because it is simply the best film I have seen this year to date.all the dancing has an exuberance (not to mention slapping of hands) that makes it patently clear that we are far from the hallowed halls of Pemberly or the civilized life of London.  But the outside locations are as sumptuous as the gilded rooms in this film, and cinematographer Roman Osin makes both look gorgeous.      For those who consider \\"Sense & Sensibility\\" to be the current cinematic benchmark for Austen adaptations I can report that \\"Pride & Prejudice\\" is its superior in terms of both romance and comedy by virtue of both crying and laughing more at this 2005 film..  Where Ang Lee's 1995 film comes out ahead is in its depiction of sisterhood, as Jane and Lizzie cannot rival Elinor and Marianne in their bonds of affection, which is understandable since it is more central to that Austen novel.  Even so there is a cute moment of confidences shared beneath the covers and Lizzie's spirited defense of her sister's shyness.  However, this one really is all about Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy.    I will not be surprised if Knightley receives a Best Actress nomination for her performance here (I still think Joan Allen is the front runner for \\"The Upside of Anger\\").  As is invariably the case with such films the cast of supporting players is superb.  Brenda Blethyn's Mrs. Bennet is the other clear Oscar contender, but Donald Sutherland as Mr. Bennet has a touching final scene with his daughter, Tom Hollander is toadally obnoxious as Mr. Collins, and my wife really wants to slap Jenna Malone's Lydia a couple of times.   We all know that this is the time of year when most of the films that will be up for Best Picture are released, and \\"Pride & Prejudice\\" has to be in the running because it is simply the best film I have seen this year to date.
B000B0WODA|4.0|Franz Ferdinand is the type of band that has successfully blended The Kinks and The Doors with the sensibilities of Blondie and The Clash. This is their formula for success, and they continue to do it well on \\"You Could Have It So Much Better\\".<br /><br />Just listen to \\"Do You Want To\\" and \\"This Boy\\". Either one could be a hit, and either one could have stepped right off of \\"Parallel Lines\\" by Blondie. Then you have \\"Eleanor But Your Boots On\\" which could have been a Kinks-meets-Marc Bolan glam rock hit. Elswhere, you have typical garagefloor dance jams like \\"I'm Your Villain\\" and punk rockers like \\"You're The Reason I'm Leaving\\" and \\"Well That Was Easy\\". In fact, I disagree with \\"The Fallen\\" being the first single. It doesn't pack the punch of some of the other material here. I personally enjoyed the Gary Numan/early Simple Minds funk of \\"Outsiders\\"--a perfect recapturing of a bygone era in popular music.<br /><br />This Scottish band has found their niche, but the future remains to be seen as to how they will grow and change if they hope to survive. To me, their first and second albums are interchangeable, but also solid works.

B0001LYH9S|5.0|I think that Outside is almost as good as Station To Station, Ziggy Stardust, Low, etc. Some people will disagree with me because of its gruesome concept that doesn't really go anywhere. Hell, even I was disturbed when I first read the inserts and heard track five, and there's hardly anything that ever shocks me! But, it's just like a scary movie. After you see it/hear it once, you're not really shocked anymore the next next time you see or hear it. I think if Bowie had added some more segues or left the concept out all together, there would be less people bashing this. Some people also say that it's too long, \\"about 80 minutes,\\" and has some filler. Personally, I think \\"Wishful Beginnings\\" is a little weaker than rest, but that's about it. <br /> <br />You're probably wondering why I gave this a five star rating. It's because of the music!!! There is nothing else that really sounds quite like it. Outside has an odd combination of industrial and jazz music, that somehow actually really works. I'm not even a big fan of either industrial or jazz, and I still really like this CD! Brian Eno, \\"Roxy music member, producer of U2's \\"The Joshua Tree,\\" \\"Achtung Baby,\\" etc.\\" is on here and he really adds to this with his synthesizers. Mark Garson also does some really good piano playing. The CD just sounds great and it feels like everyone put a lot of effort into it. Well, maybe not a whole lot of effort into the concept, but definitley the music. It's a pretty decent song, but I'd just download it instead of paying for the whole CD again. Anyway, I highly recommend this along with all of Bowie's 70's work and Scary Monsters.

0446577383|2.0|This is my first David Baldacci book and will probably be my last. Not that Baldacci isn't a fine writer: he is. But his political views set my teeth on edge. Baldacci is one of those folks who thinks that everything the United States does is tinged wiwth evil and greed. Worse he makes it clear that terrorists who murder innocent men, women and children are just oppressed folks striking back. Baldacci is certainly entitled to express his opinions, though I wouldn't think he would do too well in some of the places he claims are filled with his contemporary \\"freedom-fighters.\\"<br /><br />  Baldacci is most certainly a skilled storyteller. Oliver Stone is a mysterious man, apparently without a past, who has been engaged in a years long protest outside the White House. He even has a tent in Lafayette Park. His banner proclaims \\"I want the truth.\\" Stone and three offbeat colleagues have formed The Camel Club, where they seek to get to the bottom of the dishonesty that pervades Washington. At a late-night meeting in a public park, they watch as a man is murderered. The killers spot them, give chase and the story jumps alive.<br /><br />  Alex Ford is a Secret Service agent tasked to observe the murder investigation, the victim being an employee of a super-secreet intelligence department. Alex is paired with rookie agant Simpson, who happens to be the daughter of a powerful Senator.<br /><br />  The paths of Stone and his club members, Simpson father and daughter, Carter Gray, the nation's intelligence czar and others become increasingly intertwined. Treason is seemingly afoot. A dark conspiarcy is out there with the President as its target.<br /><br />  Baldacci holds things together until the middle of the book. The characters are all flimsy, but his storytelling his vibrant enough to take your mind off that. But then the plot goes into orbit and a solid story falls apart into strands that are clearly plucked out of thin air in an attempt to keep things going. The political rhetoric doesn't, in my opinion, help things but people with a negative view of the US won't share that view.<br /><br />  The last quarter or so of the novel simply fizzles. The plot becomes ridiculous; the action predictable and unbeleivable. The ending is not only predictable, but disappointingly dull.<br /><br />  Baldacci consistently hits the bestseller lists, so he obviously has his fans. I am just not about to become one of them. Nor will I ever become convinced as Baldacci apparently is that the United States is inherently evil and terrorists good. That just doesn't make a whole lot of sense to me. The odd thing is that the author's political polemic does nothing to advance the story. In almost every instance, it is entirely gratuitous.<br /><br />JerryThe political rhetoric doesn't, in my opinion, help things but people with a negative view of the US won't share that view. <br /> <br />  The last quarter or so of the novel simply fizzles. The plot becomes ridiculous; the action predictable and unbeleivable. The ending is not only predictable, but disappointingly dull. <br /> <br />  Baldacci consistently hits the bestseller lists, so he obviously has his fans. I am just not about to become one of them. Nor will I ever become convinced as Baldacci apparently is that the United States is inherently evil and terrorists good. That just doesn't make a whole lot of sense to me. The odd thing is that the author's political polemic does nothing to advance the story. In almost every instance, it is entirely gratuitous. <br /> <br />Jerry
B0000942HV|3.0|I'm like the majority of reviewers here: I listened to the original Tubular Bells over and over as a teenager in the 1970s.  You can't expect someone who imprinted so deeply on the original to hear this one with fresh ears.  I bought Tubular Bells 2003 because Oldfield has said it is how he had always intended the piece to sound.  I think he deserves respect and so anyone for whom the original was formative ought to give this one a listen.   <br /> <br />How many times is a master allowed to conduct, or revise, one of his own works?  Think of classical composers before recording technology.  Think of rock bands on tour.  People here have complained that there were at least five versions in thirty years.  That's once every six years.  Why is it annoying?  Yes, it's unusual for a \\"rock album.\\"  Tubular Bells is an unusual piece.  How many recordings of the Grateful Dead's \\"Truckin'\\" are there?  How many times the price of the original vinyl you bought did the value of TB turn out to be?  Back then I was poor, now I'm...less poor.  I really don't mind buying this CD just to check it out.  I don't even mind if Richard Branson gets a cut. <br /> <br />I would be most interested in the views of teenagers who heard and fell in love with this version, and then finally went back and compared the original. <br /> <br />But...I admit TB 2003 is just too shiny and voluptuous for me.  The bass is very basey.  The guitars are more like guitars.  All those...instruments!  There's often a lot of high fizzy sound-- the original had a lot of Farfisa organ, but this one sort of brings it out for you to, er, appreciate and keep appreciating.  Oldfield uses a lot of constant sounds to create atmosphere.  Here they seem less subliminal.  The old piece is like a banquet of Indian curry dishes.  This one is like a meal at a fancy restaurant where every dish is carefully presented on a big plate, in a puddle of purple sauce, decorated with parsely and sculptured bits of carrot. <br /> <br />One minor thing--it can be very disturbing to have this in your iPod on shuffle-all-my-music, and have one of the sections of Tubular Bells play and then suddenly end before the first note of the next section! <br /> <br />It may be that the piece that everyone loved in 1974 was not the piece Oldfield intended, but more of an accident of tape hiss, fatigue, distortion, lack of money and lack of time.  Or maybe most music shouldn't sound exactly the way the composer intended, and modern tech tempts musicians down a garden path of control and perfectionism.  My TB-ROM was burnt long ago.  But it would be interesting to hear Tubular Bells 2003 get a fair trial.

B00003XAQ5|5.0|Now with the SACD version I have hit my fifth copy of the great classic: original off-pitch CD issue, pitch corrected CD with bonus track, Davis/Coltrane Columbia box set, bootleg Complete Session and SACD.  It's a pity that the SACD release didn't take the opportunity to issue the complete sessions which includes breakdowns and studio talk. <br /> <br />All the reviews I have read of this release miss what this very obviously is: a transfer of the three channel master or safety.  Blue was recorded to three track with tenor/piano in one, trumpet/bass in 2 and alto/drums in three which neatly corresponds to L/C/R on the SACD.  There is breakthrough from the instruments into each of the channels as the horn mikes were kept fully open during the recording.  The drums were clearly isolated as there is very little breakthrough from them.  Much the same for the bass so you do really need a full-range centre speaker to give justice to Paul Chambers.  There is no sub channel and the rear is just digital reverb so I turn it off as the original recording was sweetened with some reverb. <br /> <br />If you have the pitch-correct CD then this is not essential as the stereo mix is quite excellent and gives an expansiveness to all the instruments.  However if you are seriously into Miles then this is worth it with his trumpet fully on show in the centre channel.  I again must emphasis -you will need a full range centre speaker not the standard restricted range ones provided in surround-sound systems i.e. missing the low octave or two which contains the double bass's lowest notes.  I rebuilt mine when I got the SACD Tommy which had Entwhistle's bass centre channel - 2 x 6\\" speakers didn't cut it even with a sub. <br />
B0007OCG4W|3.0|\\"Closer,\\" if nothing else, is a refreshing change for major movie releases in that it truly defies established formulas.  If your best friend said that there was a new movie about love and romance and it stars Julia Roberts, Natalie Portman, and Jude Law (plus the rakishly handsome Clive Owen), you'd probably leap to the conclusion that a studio had tried to make \\"Love Actually II\\" or some other sappy romantic comedy.    Nothing could be further from the truth.  In a movie that revolves intensely around the four leads as two couples who, shall we say, \\"interact,\\" it's hard to find a likable chap or gal.  Selfishness and betrayal rule the day, along with graphic language about sex.  I'm not talking overly clinical language, I'm talking about the language of people who use sex as a means to establish dominance and superiority, not intimacy or even enjoyment.  Guilt and shame are at least as prevalent as love and affection, and truth may be the rarest commodity of all.    Be warned -- this is not a feel-good movie in any way.  That's not to say that it's a \\"bad movie,\\" of course.  My three-star rating stems from the fact that the movie spans a few years, yet the transitions between leaps forward and flashes back are confusing, and the characters generally talk like movie characters and not real people (listening to Jude Law explain his job as a writer of obituaries rings false, and I'm not sure a woman like Natalie Portman's character \\"Alice\\" has ever walked the earth).     Still, if you're looking for a dark examination of the war between the sexes (and we are talking about war), and you've worn out your copy of \\"In the Company of Men,\\" or you find \\"The War of the Roses\\" too cheery, this may be just the movie for you.

B00005JO1J|3.0|\\"Rent\\" is a thrilling, emotional experience on the stage: take it from someone who has seen the show on Broadway twice and in a primo road show version in Los Angeles starring Dougie Howser (Neil Patrick Harris) three times.<br />But that was a number of years ago and though this Chris Columbus directed filmed version of \\"Rent\\" tries awfully hard to recapture the revolutionary feel of the new-to-Broadway-in-1994 subject matter (AIDS, drug addiction, etc.) and the re-writing and re-imagining of Puccini's \\"La Boheme\\" (by the super-talented Jonathan Larson)...it doesn't, though a couple of the scenes are knockouts: Mimi's (a dynamic, sultry, sexy Rosario Dawson) \\"Out Tonight\\" and the touching scene between Mimi and Roger (Adam Pascal) \\"Light My Candle.\\"<br />Overall there is a nagging feeling of been there done that about this entire film though once again I must re-iterate: the songs are first rate at least and glorious at best plus all the performers do a bang-up job of singing, acting and dancing.<br />Unfortunately and frankly most of the performers are just too old for these parts: all of these actors were in the original Broadway production some 10 years ago. Remember this is a story about Gen X early twenty year olds and though they perform well: Adam Pascal, Wilson Jermaine Heredia, Anthony Rapp and Idina Menzel (Mark, Roger, Angel and Maureen) look like what they are, mid-thirty year olds. More importantly though, an essentially young person's concerns, problems and manner of looking at life juxtaposed onto someone who appears well into his or her 30's makes the characters pathetic and hopeless rather than tragic and hopeful and this friction irreparably damages the film to it's core.<br />Sadly then, \\"Rent\\" is a disappointment: a case of a show with excellent bones whose body begs, really needs to be updated to transform it into as smartly cast, cogent, with-it, and profound as it was 10+ years ago.

B000BNX3B4|2.0|It seems a shame that a movie starring two of the more likable screen actors today, Diane Lane and John Cusack, would end up being such an overly deliberate Hollywood contrivance. Although the film topically addresses the world of online matchmaking, it doesn't feel relevant given the tendency toward convention. It's not too surprising to find out that this is the product of TV sitcom director-writer Gary David Goldberg as it feels like there is an absent laugh track with pauses after certain line readings to make room for the gales of laughter that never really come. This is the type of movie that depends on a sing-along with \\"The Partridge Family\\" theme song for a nostalgic guffaw.<br /><br />The story centers on Sarah, an attractive, fortyish woman freshly divorced and prodded by her meddlesome family to start dating again. I think it could have helped if Lane, wallowing in self-doubt and analysis paralysis, did not play such a similar character in last year's \\"Under the Tuscan Sun\\". This time she's a pre-school teacher with - surprise! - a love for dogs. As is routine with this sort of set-up, Sarah is surrounded by stock characters - an acid-tongued, married older sister, Carol, who submits Sarah's online profile behind her back; a bromide-spouting father with a brogue that would make Barry Fitzgerald wince; a happily partnered colleague with a heart of gold; and Bob, a recently separated man who may or may not have the best intentions in pursuing Sarah. Complicating matters is Jake, an iconoclastic, \\"Doctor Zhivago\\"-loving boat-builder who immediately falls for Sarah.<br /><br />Even though Lane is as lovely as usual (and constantly reminded of this by her family) and Cusack seems to default easily back to his Lloyd Dobler persona from \\"Say Anything\\", it's hard to see why Jake falls for Sarah given her continuing trepidation, but alas, that seems to be the only viable point of conflict in the plot since there is so little character development. A sturdy supporting cast is wasted - Elizabeth Perkins back to second-banana status as the sister; Christopher Plummer somewhere between twinkly philosopher and aging lothario as the father; Dermot Mulroney whose character Bob is made so inconsistent as to render his subplot confusing; Ben Shenkman irritating as Jake's sleazy lawyer best friend and Stockard Channing sorely misused as a trailer-park hippie woman infatuated with Sarah's father.<br /><br />Granted there are a few chuckles (for example, when they careen through town hunting for a condom), the movie feels disjointed with scenes that simply stop and start with little sense of plot development other than getting to its inevitable ending. Goldberg doesn't have the sensibilities of a Cameron Crowe to get away with such an eccentric cast of characters, and the plot just feels overloaded with clich&eacute;s. Even with Lane and Cusack, the film should sadly be passed over.ted - Elizabeth Perkins back to second-banana status as the sister; Christopher Plummer somewhere between twinkly philosopher and aging lothario as the father; Dermot Mulroney whose character Bob is made so inconsistent as to render his subplot confusing; Ben Shenkman irritating as Jake's sleazy lawyer best friend and Stockard Channing sorely misused as a trailer-park hippie woman infatuated with Sarah's father. Goldberg doesn't have the sensibilities of a Cameron Crowe to get away with such an eccentric cast of characters, and the plot just feels overloaded with clichs. Even with Lane and Cusack, the film should sadly be passed over.
B000002AHC|5.0|I first heard this album in a friend's record collection and decided to buy it. Yes this album is dated but not nearly as much as say 70's arena rock. This is clearly the high water mark of the Byrds career, when they stopped copping Dylan and found their sound. Psychadelic, with more than a touch of country (which would eventually overwhelm their albums)and Moog trappings, the album works. I don't really care about the conflict between David Crosby and the rest of the band (the bonus tracks are skippable). What I see in this album is a wistful sincerity for childhood and innocence. A song like \\"Change is Now\\" with the refrain, \\"dance for the day when fear is gone\\" suddenly sounds eerily contemporary.  And as for the more dated songs like Dolphin's Smile and Space Odyssey are redeemed by the effects (which took weeks if not months of overdubbing at the time).  I can't say this album is ahead of its time or pre-punk or anything else people use to make acceptable to enjoy an album of this kind.  Its just good pop songs, with wit and intelligence, something hard if not impossible to find in mainstream rock these days.
