B00005JOHI|4.0|When I heard that there was a new version of \\"Pride and Prejudice\\" to be made, I was far from pleased. In fact, I was fairly annoyed: A&E's version with Colin Firth has been a staple of my DVD collection for an incredibly long time, and I couldn't imagine anyone tampering with perfection. Why mess with genius?<br /><br />Happily, I was wrong in my estimation of the movie. Perhaps it's only appropriate, given the subject matter: the whole story of \\"Pride and Prejudice\\" is wrapped up in wrong estimations of character, miscommunications, and partial understandings. The Focus Features version of \\"Pride and Prejudice\\" is more of a classic Romance, set earlier in period and filmed against more stunning backdrops than the A&E version: there were no grand cliffs or windswept heaths in that one, but they work here.<br /><br />The performances are universally excellent: I was appropriately annoyed by Brenda Blethyn's ludicrously inappropriate Mrs. Bennet, and Judi Dench as Lady Catherine de Bourgh is one of the most delicious strokes of casting genius...ever. Donald Sutherland as the bemused patriarch Mr. Bennet holds his own in a largely British cast, and was suitably affectionately distracted in his fatherly role. Simon Woods is amiable and open-faced as Mr. Bingley, and properly deserves Rosamund Pike's delicate Jane.<br /><br />The movie belongs, however, to Matthew McFadyen and Keira Knightley, as it rightly should. The book, however involved its subplots, focused mainly on their sparring, and the film wisely excises a lot of the extraneous matter, tightening its focus and condensing some scenes. Matthew McFadyen is, possibly, an even better Mr. Darcy than Colin Firth (though that pains me to say): his Darcy is sensitive, prone to moodiness and shows of the Stiff Upper Lip, but his eyes don't always manage to keep up the mask, and it is this that makes him amazing. When his eyes do light up, it is stunning, because we have learned not to expect it. He positively smolders with passion, even soaking wet with pleading in his eyes. Or perhaps especially soaking wet. In any case, he smolders. Bosoms will heave, corsets or not, when he's onscreen.<br /><br />Watching Keira Knightley as Lizzie Bennet I was irresistibly reminded of another fiercely intelligent, wide-eyed brunette bookworm: Winona Ryder's Jo March, in 1994's exquisite \\"Little Women.\\" Knightley conveys the same compelling blend of delicacy and strength as Ryder managed, no easy feat in this world of one-note romance, and one I wasn't sure she could manage, as I've never been a fan. Knightley does a good job, however: her Lizzie is a \\"fearsome creature,\\" to quote herself, both fiercely loyal and heartily passionate for life, yet always with just a trace of vulnerability; one wonders, at times, if her passionate demeanour isn't as much a disguise as Darcy's cool mask. Perhaps that is what makes their inevitable but much-delayed romance so alluring: here are two people who absolutely should be in love with each other, but manage to think themselves out of it for a very long time.<br /><br />The world of the film is more realistically rural than other adaptations: the ladies' hems are dirty, their dresses are frequently wrinkled, and pigs traipse through the Bennet house as often as visitors do. There are some lovely little touches to the filmmaking as well, such as one scene featuring a distracted Mr. Darcy being circled, predator-like, by Lizzie and the coolly condescending Caroline Bingley; one absolutely feels sorry for the man. I particularly liked the dancing scenes: there is always something going on with someone familiar in the corner of the frame, lending the scenes a pleasant intimacy that suits the material nicely.<br /><br />Ultimately, I love this story so much because its romantic heroes deserve one another, even though they do not always realize it. Theirs is a relationship built not only on passion - although in this version, even more so than the seminal A&E version, it is decidedly present, particularly in a post-wedding scene at Pemberley featuring (sigh!) a barefoot Mr. Darcy - but on mutual interests and a hearty respect for one another. When Lizzie and Darcy finally marry (as we know they must, long before they do) it is, to steal from Shakespeare (and another Jane Austen movie) a \\"marriage of true minds.\\" And after all, what could be more romantic than a smart, handsome man in a cravat and a long, windblown coat?a post-wedding scene at Pemberley featuring (sigh!) a barefoot Mr. Darcy - but on mutual interests and a hearty respect for one another. When Lizzie and Darcy finally marry (as we know they must, long before they do) it is, to steal from Shakespeare (and another Jane Austen movie) a \\"marriage of true minds.\\" And after all, what could be more romantic than a smart, handsome man in a cravat and a long, windblown coat?
B00005JOHI|5.0|Some considerable time ago, I watched the BBC miniseries presentation of PRIDE AND PREJUDICE, a chick-flick if there ever was one starring Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle, at the urging of a Jane Austen-obsessed female friend. When I reluctantly admitted that I thoroughly enjoyed it, I realized that I must resign my long-standing membership in the Neanderthal Male Fellowship. Now, much to my horror and apparently diminished masculinity, I have to say that this 2005 version of P & P was even more captivating and better than the BBC version in all respects, albeit much shorter in length.<br /><br />The plot of P & P needs no extensive recapitulation here; if you don't know it by now after many cinematic renderings, then forget it. Briefly, the story surrounds five unwed daughters of a son-less English country gentleman, Mr. Bennet (Donald Sutherland), in financial decline in the early 19th century (or, as in this new version, the late 18th). The girls, particularly the eldest Jane (Rosamund Pike), the second eldest, Elizabeth (Keira Knightley), and the third eldest, Lydia (Jena Malone), get caught up in a romantic tangle with a plethora of would-be suitors: the perky young gentleman Charles Bingley (Simon Woods), the darkly moody young nobleman Darcy (Matthew Macfadyen), the dashing Army officer Lt. Wickham (Rupert Friend), and the weasley cleric cousin William Collins (Tom Hollander). The girls' fear of impending spinsterhood is whipped into a froth by the maternal anxieties of their foolish and marriage-obsessed mother (Brenda Blethyn). Mr. Bennet accepts his fate as the sole male in this estrogen-driven household with a certain bemused resignation. In any case, the focus of the story is on Elizabeth (\\"Lizzie\\") and Darcy, whom the former initially despises as arrogant and boorish. It's Darcy's pride and Lizzie's prejudice that must come to terms in this comic opera of social customs and manners.<br /><br />This version of P & P has been criticized by purists for at least two reasons, both of which are irrelevant to me since I haven't read, nor do I intend to read, the original Austen novel. First, the financial health of the Bennet clan is, apparently, reduced from that in the book (and, indeed, from that in the BBC miniseries). Indeed, while the family still employs servants and seems to have enough food on the table, their lifestyle here is noticeably more seedy - almost grubby - than previously depicted. Well, why not? It's this desperate condition caused by an aging patriarch and lack of a male heir that has Mom and her brood worked into a frenzy about their future prospects. Indeed, cousin William, due to inherit the estate on Mr. Bennet's death, is already nosing around inspecting the goods. Second, fault has been found with Macfadyen's Darcy as less obstinate, i.e. self-assured, in his pride than Firth's version. Now, while I readily admit that Firth's Darcy is perhaps his career's best role, I find Colin generally to be a Lump in all his screen roles. Matthew's version displays an anguished vulnerability beneath the proud veneer that's tapped by his attraction to Keira's Lizzie. And what man in his right mind wouldn't be? Keira's version is a Bewitching Babe with two capital Bs. (All through the screening, I strained to remember where I'd seen Macfadyen before; he's not exactly a familiar face on American Big Screens. Afterwards, I remembered that he plays the lead in the current British telly miniseries \\"MI5\\".)<br /><br />This P & P, as befitting a major production, has cinematography that is, at times, positively luminous, and the camera work is more adroit and clever than anything seen previous. Three scenes were, for me, particularly memorable: the visual isolation of Lizzie and Darcy from the rest of the revelers at The Ball, Lizzie's changing view of the Bennet estate as she spins in a swing hung under an arch, and Mrs. Bennet's inclusion, white petticoats flying, in a flock of scurrying white, silly geese as she pursues a rebellious daughter across the yard. These visuals were positively inspired.<br /><br />There are no acting performances here anything less than superb. Special mention must be given to Judi Dench as the imperious Lady Catherine, Sutherland as the overwhelmed, gentle Mr. Bennet, and Hollander's brilliant rendition of the pathetic Collins.<br /><br />Yes, I like this PRIDE AND PREJUDICE more than I can adequately explain. It may, perhaps, land a place on my Ten Most Favorite Films list.she pursues a rebellious daughter across the yard. These visuals were positively inspired. <br /> <br />There are no acting performances here anything less than superb. Special mention must be given to Judi Dench as the imperious Lady Catherine, Sutherland as the overwhelmed, gentle Mr. Bennet, and Hollander's brilliant rendition of the pathetic Collins. <br /> <br />Yes, I like this PRIDE AND PREJUDICE more than I can adequately explain. It may, perhaps, land a place on my Ten Most Favorite Films list.  <br />
B00005JO1P|5.0|\\"Walk the line\\" is one of the few films that had a lot of hype surrounding it that managed to surpass my expectations.  Upon first hearing that there was a Johnny Cash biopic film starring Joaquin Phoenix and Reese Witherspoon, I didn't really think much of it.  I thought they're just trying to \\"cash\\" in on the popularity of \\"Ray\\" from last year.  And the actors!  I couldn't really picture Phoenix and Witherspoon doing justice to Johnny and June.  While both are fine actors it really takes a special talent and can be really risky portraying country music legends such as Cash and Carter.  Then, I heard that \\"Walk the line\\" got good reviews from a number of critics.  And, my friends who saw it also spoke very highly of it.  After seeing it yesterday, I consider it the best movie of the year and worthy of oscar nominations.   <br /> <br />The story focuses mainly on Johnny and June Carter.  There are alot of similarities in this film with \\"Ray\\", but the main difference is that the complexity of his relationship with June is shown more here as a saving grace than Ray's wife was.  The director allows this focus to give insight to how songs were written by both Cash and Carter.  It's interesting after hearing Cash and Carter's songs for so long to finally see the circumstances surrounding their lives which inspired them.    <br /> <br />Phoenix and Witherspoon both give the performance of their careers.  Both their voices are amazingly accurate to the originals.  With Phoenix managing to hit all the right notes with a suprisingly almost perfect timbre, while Witherspoon sings well and even with a Carter-ish growl.  The chemistry these two posess between eachother makes it easy for the audience to believe Johnny's love for June as well as June's reluctance to marry Johnny for so many years.  Both deserve a nomination for best actor and actress, since they both nail their respective parts.  Out of the two, I think Phoenix is more likely to win an oscar because his portrayalof Johnny is so beleivable.  Johnny's vulnerability and wild side are portrayed with ease by Phoenix.  Phoenix has a talent for giving deep, probing characters with an emotional side and he not only does that but he seems to channel Cash through him and never once does the audience look at him and not think he is Cash.  Kudos to the rest of the cast but Witherspoon and Phoenix really make the film as well as the writers and director James Mangold.   <br /> <br />\\"Walk the line\\" is touching, powerful, and highly recommended!
B000AYQLX6|5.0|This superb re-issue of John Lennon's WALLS AND BRIDGES does indeed have a booklet; a 12-page booklet, in fact, which reproduces the entire booklet issued in 1974 with the original 12-inch LP and adds a picture. (One picture from the photo session in the original insert has been replaced with a similar one from the same session, but this is not a drastic change.) Lennon's original list of musicians is intact, so it includes such humorous psuedonyms for himself as Mel Torment and the Rev. Thumbs Ghurkin. The booklet reproduces the full-page history of the name Lennon from the original insert, with Lennon's snappy hand-written response to the claim that no one with his name ever achieved anything: \\"Oh, yeh?\\" So, attention to Lennon's original has been paid. The lift-the-flap cover isn't there anymore, but, the pictures which were part of it are there, so, I say this packaging is a pretty good tribute to the original. The LP, when first released in 1975, had pristine sound, which had not been the case with Lennon's previous album, MIND GAMES, which had muddy sound. (MIND GAMES has been re-mastered recently and sounds much clearer than it used to sound.) So, this new CD of WALLS AND BRIDGES is not a drastic change from the original LP, because the LP was crystal clear. What has been done here is a restoration to the original sound. The first CD issue of WALLS AND BRIDGES didn't sound nearly as clear as the vinyl but the new release does sound like the vinyl and that's great. Some of the tracks have been merely re-mixed, but some have been re-mastered. I think this means that the restoration team did not want to change anything too much and that they were careful to re-master only when necessary. <br />By the way, I paid $18.99 at an independent record shop, so I don't see this as in anyway overpriced. I imagine the big record outlets will sell it for a few dollars less.  <br />The three bonus tracks are perfect for this CD. One is the live version of \\"Whatever Gets YouThrough The Night\\" which Elton John and John Lennon played at Madison Square Garden, one is a demo of \\"Nobody Loves You When You're Down and Out\\" featuring Lennon's voice and his accoustic guitar and the third is a brief but interesting promotional interview Lennon recorded for EMI records when this album was first released. It is the last track on the CD so the interview does not interrupt the music. <br />Lennon is in command here. If the horns are a bit heavy, they do match the somber mood of this intelligent work from a man who was spending too many nights at after hours bars and knew it. Jesse Ed Davis's curvaceous guitar sound is vital to WALLS AND BRIDGES.  If you think of \\"#9 Dream\\" and love the opening guitar, thank Jesse Ed Davis. <br />This is Lennon the craftsman. He once described \\"#9 Dream\\" as a \\"written\\" song, adding that he hadn't invested any emotion in it. Perhaps what I admire about this album is its lack of overt emotion. Lennon's understated performance here is what makes it great.   <br /> <br />
B000B8QEZG|3.0|Dear Madonna, <br /> <br />As most of your devoted fans, I eagerly awaited the arrival of your new album, Confessions on A Dance Floor.  However, it seems that all of my eager anticipation and high hopes were truly in vain.  I can't say I hated the new material.  I will always have some affinity for the work you do, because after all...you are Madonna! <br /> <br />That being said, after have my initial listen to the new album, I was a little more than nonplussed by what I heard.  If this had been an album by one of your wannabe progeny like Britney or Christina, or even one of your inferior contemporaries like Kylie, I would have been more impressed.  After all, these gals don't write and produce their own material (at least not with any grand success).  And they are hardly self-invented the way you are.  No matter how hard they try, they will not ever be Madonna! <br /> <br />As a long time fan (since the beginning-honestly) I have had a truly rare bird's-eye view of your career through your inceptions, your sudden rise to meteoric fame, your transition into goddess (forget diva) status, and beyond.  I could see what you were doing and what you aught to be doing, sometimes before you yourself could see it.  I could have told you that you should have been collaborating with Shep Pettibone and William Orbit long before you actually decided to do it.  Perhaps most of your fans don't truly recognize your patterns-actions and reactions to your previous works and their successes and missteps (I dislike the word \\"failures\\")-quite the way I might. <br /> <br />Music was the first disc in a while that seems far less self conscious and much more focused on just good `ol dance music.  You were still forging new territory by tingeing the sound with a little retro 80s.  The title track is still one of my favorites. <br /> <br />Then came American Life.  OK, so I realize things in the States were (and still are) truly screwed up politically and other wise, but we needed you tobe the one who brought us some much needed escapism.  Leave the political rants to Bono.  And the further self examination of your fame and the loss of your mother was becoming too much for any of us to bear.   The post 9-11 world truly changed all of our priorities, and celebrities whining about their own pain and frustration meant little.  We were too wrapped up in our own.  But the true breaking point too this album was the incessant droning on of electronically modulated voices.  This was beyond my comprehension.  You were definitely repeating yourself.   <br /> <br />So that brings us to Confessions on a Dance Floor.  I'm still not sure were to begin with this one... <br /> <br />I'll start with the more obvious, albeit rare highpoints.  Sorry, Future Lovers, Jump, How High, Push, and Like It or Not are definitely the most inspired bits.  The rest of it is largely forgettable and almost pointless.  I strain to hear what, beyond your voice, you contributed to these songs.  They are lack-luster and ordinary.  Stewart Price, while probably a great tour conductor, is no Patrick Leonard.  I was glad to see Mirwais was very minimal in his contributions at this time, I was left wanting more contributions from Bloodshy & Avant.  The most richly textured song was Like it or Not, both lyrically and sonically.  Why these guys weren't found in greater quantities I'll never know. <br /> <br />But more importantly, I'm left wondering why there weren't more collaborations with both seasoned veterans and the pick of the new crop of talent out there today.  Madonna, you could work with anyone you wanted to!! Clearly Pat Leonard has been one of your most prolific song writing and producing partners.  Bringing him back for Ray of Light was genius and the paring of his classically trained ear with the nouveau electronic wizardry of William Orbit created some of the most lavishly produced stuff you've ever made (i.e. Frozen). Shep was also a good partner for you.  He's never received another chance.  What about Nelly Hooper?  Bedtime Story was a sonic revelation.  And then there are a host of others you've not tried like BT (Brian Transeau), Tracy Young, Calderone, and many others who have remixed your songs.  The way you love to modulate your voice, I would think that the paring of you and BT would thrill you to death.  <br /> <br />All I can figure is that you were disappointed about the lack of attention that American Life got.  It was full of innovation, but it lacked hooks.  Mirwais is an awesome talent, no doubt, but why not water him down a bit with other co-song writers and producers?  It would still work. Perhaps this scared you into playing it safe.  Well, it was too safe this time and largely uninspiring.  You're Madonna.  You don't have to play it safe any more.  <br /> <br />Don't worry, I still love you and always will.  You've gone on in ways that most of your class of the 1980s never could.  Prince, Cyndi Lauper, Michael Jackson, Janet Jackson, and Paula Abdul will never get this chance.  Anytime they try to make a new album it will be considered a come back.  You never left us, and for that I am truly grateful. <br /> <br />I'm already looking forward to your next effort.  M should always stand for Madonna, not mediocre.  <br /> <br />Yours always, <br /> <br />A rabid fan!
B000068PQ0|4.0|Yep, it's pretty weird. And that's coming from someone who regularly listens to experimental jazz and Japanese noise... Well, I guess I should say it's weird in a different way to what you might expect.    \\"Yoshimi Battles The Pink Robots\\" is definitely one of the 'poppiest' albums I've purchased in a long while. It's full of beautiful songs with oddly triumphant (but at the same time often heart-breaking) lyrics. But throughout, as with most Flaming Lips stuff, there are dark, experimental layers which you could very well miss on a casual listen. For example electronic rumblings or crazy guitar feedback could be bubbling in the background, but your focus is generally on the pop gem in the foreground... or is it?     Anyway, then get this - tracks like \\"One More Robot\\" and \\"Yoshimi Battles the Pink Robots pt.1\\" feature big funky beats that wouldn't be out of place on a hip/trip-hop album (are they doing this because they don't know any better, are they trying to be 'funny', or is it all fully intentional? It doesn't really matter, because somehow it just *works*). I've heard nearly every style blended with every other style, but here it just seems 'so wrong it's right' - even if it's all absolutely deliberate it still has a certain naivety which is touching and refreshing. It's kind of like Radiohead without the self-consciousness (but don't get me wrong, I do like Radiohead).    Most reviews mention the 'hits' \\"Yoshimi..\\" and \\"Do You Realize??\\", and these are indeed great tunes. My album highlights though are \\"In The Morning Of The Magicians\\" with it's floating off-beat verse and funny little snippets of 'chamber-midi', and the deranged choral love song \\"Are You A Hypnotist??\\".    My only complaint with this album is the opening track. As was noted when it was released as a single, \\"Fight Test\\" sounds very much like Cat Stevens' \\"Father And Son\\" and The Flaming Lips faced a bit of trouble and I believe they ended up having to pay Stevens royalties. Let's face it, \\"Fight Test\\" isn't a great song anyway, and definitely not worth the trouble. Usually I look to the first track of an album for a 'big bang' and something that represents the album, but here I just have to skip it every time I listen unfortunately.     But not wanting to end on a sour note, I will say that the other 10 tracks are brilliant. Highly recommended! (4.5 out of 5)

I first read To Kill a Mockingbird at school nearly three decades ago and since that time I must have read it at least once each year. This has helped me develop a deep understanding for Harper Lee's master work. The central characters of this book are two children Scout and Jem, who live with their father Atticus, a lawyer. The story is set in a fictional town called Maycombe in the depression ravaged 1930s America, though the people of America have just been told that the only thing they have to fear is fear itself.<br /><br />My favourite parts of this book are the way a child is able to disperse a murder intent mob, the power of the court room scenes and the way that the children eventually see things so clearly, maybe more clearly than any adult does throughout the pages of To Kill a Mockingbird. As Scout puts it: \\"...you never really understand somebody until you step into their shoes and walk around in them.\\" If we all applied that wisdom, how much better the world would be.<br /><br />I personally loved the way Harper Lee describes this small town and its quaint little ways, while at the same time realising that this quaintness hides attitudes that are tainted by class distinctions and prejudice. The book goes on to relate this prejudice that comes to the surface in a dramatic fashion and forces people to look very carefully at their own attitudes, while at the same time exposing a simple truth that when people have been brought up with deep prejudices it is very difficult to shake these off. But To Kill a Mockingbird demonstrates that when prejudice is confronted in the minds of those who are prejudiced then the truth can be very different to the one previously supposed.<br /><br />Nobody should make the mistake of thinking that this book should only be read by those who are at school doing their exams, because to miss reading this book would be a real shame. I would recommend that everybody buy this book and read it again and again. Neither did \\"The First Time\\" for that matter, a lesser song on the masterpiece \\"Zooropa\\". Then hits and fan favorites like \\"The Fly\\" are nowhere to be found, although they were singles. I can see why \\"Lemon\\" wasn't included though; that would sound out of place on this album.    On the good side though, quite a bit of non-album U2 is represented. The William Orbit mix of \\"Electrical Storm\\" is amazing, one of my favorite U2 songs ever. It's a nice Britpop song. \\"The Hand That Built America\\" is decent as well, although not amazing. The other non-album tracks include the \\"Batman & Robin\\" hit \\"Hold Me...\\", which is one of the closest things to industrial that U2 did in that decade. Its edginess showed why U2 were so much more than a run-of-the-mill pop band they would've been had they gone from \\"Joshua\\" to \\"ATYCLB\\". A track they did in their Passengers moniker appears as well, \\"Miss Sarajevo\\", which is really quite interesting. In addition, it includes the three classics I mentioned in the first half, which don't require a description of the excellence.    Without the flaws, this could have been a great retrospective of the second decade in U2's music. It was actually better in the 90s than the 80's in this person's humble opinion, but the compilation does not do anything to suggest that. Just take note of the stuff worth actually owning.
B00000342V|5.0|No serious music fan can be without some version of _Superfly_, it's really that simple... I agree with some reviewers here that the second disc in the 25th Annniv.  edition isn't all essential material. The one truly essential item on the second disc is \\"The Underground\\" (demo). It's insanely great - one of the best, most soulful grooves I've ever heard. A gift from the gods. Finding it is a little like having, say, \\"Penny Lane\\" turn up for the first time on one of the Beatles _Anthology_ records. <br />So... if you are a Curtis M. fan you *have* to have this track.
0783225857|5.0|To Kill a Mockingbird is without doubt Gregory Peck's finest work. When the author of To Kill a Mockingbird first saw Gregory Peck she was not convinced that he was the man to play the central role of Atticus Finch, indeed she thought him too young. But when she first saw Gregory Peck playing Atticus she remarked that it was like seeing her beloved \\"Daddy\\". When you watch Gregory Peck playing Atticus Finch, he is so natural in the role, that you sense that he was born to play this role.<br /><br />This film's screenplay adaptation of Harper Lee's book concentrates mainly on the courtroom scenes. But this film also considers other elements from the book too, including the relationship between the three children Scout, Jem and Dill with Boo Radley. Look out for the scene where the children decide to investigate the Radley home under the cover of darkness, the courtroom scene where Atticus appeals to the jury and the scene where Scout stops a murder intent mob in it's tracks. Though shot in black and white this does not rob the film of it's impact, indeed I felt the lack of colour gives the film a raw power all of its own. Furthermore, I guarantee that after watching this film you will want to read or indeed reread the book.<br /><br />Both Gregory Peck's father and Harper Lee's father had sadly died soon after the end of production. Before Gregory Peck went to the Oscar ceremony Harper Lee gave him her father's gold watch for luck. It worked! At the Oscar ceremony Gregory Peck at long last received his highly deserved Oscar. A fitting tribute to a man that many people have come to view as Atticus Finch himself.

Sound familiar, I'm sure it does. <br />     Brilliantly directed, photographed, and with amazing performances and charachters (Norton, Pitt and Carter at the top of their games), Fight Club has it all for you movie buffs out there. B000B8QEZG|4.0|...and you'll find a somewhat different Madonna molded from the same Madonna we knew from the 80's. While the seriousness from American Life and Ray of Light can still be found on some songs on Dancefloor, the music itself is reminiscent of disco pop, a sort of techno-disco-ish version of her 80's sound.<br /><br />One listen to the catchy \\"Hung Up,\\" the silly \\"I Love New York,\\" and the dark \\"How High,\\" you'll see that she's having fun again. Bringing in sounds from the disco era (\\"Hung Up\\" and \\"Future Lovers\\") to Daft Punk (\\"Get Together\\" and \\"Forbidden Love\\") to even modern pop (\\"Push\\"), the disc is crafted to make the listener dance, even if some of the songs do start out and end the same. But that's just a little drawback; some of the best dance discs out there have been accused of repetitiveness.<br /><br />Clocking in at just a tad over 56 minutes, the disc is a blessing welcome in mainstream music nowadays, one which is filled with uninspired rap/hip-hop/R&B. Saying that Madonna has come back with a vengeance is an over-statement but rather, she has come back dancing again, infecting her long-time and new fans alike.

B0000AQS6R|4.0|I've long been a fan of the \\"Vacation\\" films, as well as National Lampoon movies in general.  \\"Christmas Vacation\\" is the third-best Lampoon movie and the second-best of the \\"Vacation\\" series.  Chevy Chase returns as Clark Griswold Jr., who is this time set on making this year's Christmas one to remember.  He did it. <br /> <br />Chase is at best and funniest.  Beverly D'Angelo returns as Ellen Griswold, with the Griswold kids now portrayed by Johnny Galecki and a young Juliette Lewis.  Diane Ladd, John Randolph, E.G. Marshall, and Doris Roberts are the grandparents.  Randy Quaid is hilarious in his return as Cousin Eddy.  Brian Doyle-Murray is, as always, great, as Clark's angry, cold-hearted boss.  Nicholas Guest and Julia Louis-Dreyfus play Clark's rich, stuck-up neighbors. <br /> <br />The soundtrack is actually very good.  It's filled with some great Christmas tunes, along with a good score by the amazing Angelo Badalamenti.   <br /> <br />John Hughes' script is terrific.  We can believe what the Griswold family is going through because we've gone through it too.  But Hughes' script isn't all laugh-out-loud comedy; at it's heart, it's a message about a caring father who tries to make the best Christmas for his family.  There's one scene where Clark can't get the Christmas lights to work, and all the family members say comforting things to him; I thought it was actually a pretty moving scene. <br /> <br />\\"Christmas Vacation\\" is great, hilarious Christmas fun.  If you're looking for a new movie this Christmas season, give this one a shot.
B000021XS0|5.0|If you're new to Dream Theater, it wouldn't be a bad idea to start here, as this album is up there with Images and Words and Awake. This album is a concept album that must be listened through from beginning to end to get the full effect. The music here is very complex but with a modern touch to it, giving it that classic rock/metal feel at times, while at the same time being very progressive. John Petrucci has a great guitar sound throughout the entire album - actually, every instrument comes through very clear in the mix. The reverb heard on previous records is now replaced by more of a roomy sound, which I think suits the band much better.  <br /> <br />Bottom line, Dream Theater has always been a band that musically pushes the envelope with each album, and on this album they have done it to a great degree. Five stars.
B000BM6AVA|4.0|Since their debut, System of a Down have been one of the most original and pioneering bands in rock music. It is a testament to their quality as a band that their works have been so consistent and so true to their style. Their vision of a dual album Mesmerize/Hypnotize was an ambitious one. Double albums are always a tricky thing to pull off, and more bands have failed than succeeded in this regard. To this extent, System of a Down have to praised for so thoughtfully realizing and delivering a double album that does maintain unity. However, some slight errors of judgment by System of a Down leave this album a notch below classic status.  <br /> <br />Firstly, System made a wise choice by separating the release of each album by 6 months. Releasing them together would have been a bit too much to handle. \\"Attack\\", the opener of the album is all out hellfire. It is fierce and vicious, and Malakian and Dolmayan play it at a nearly superhuman speed. \\"Dreaming\\", \\"Kill Rock'N'Roll\\", and \\"Hypnotize\\" are all quality songs. \\"Tentative\\", \\"U-Fig\\", and \\"Holy Mountains\\" along with \\"Attack\\" have to be the best songs on the album. Overall, the quality of the lyrics in Hypnotize has drastically improved over Mesmerize. \\"Tentative\\" and \\"Holy Mountains\\" have some of the best choruses on the entire double CD set. <br /> <br />It is here where we are treated to some the worst System of a Down songs on this album (and possibly ever recorded). \\"Vicinity of Obscenity\\", \\"She's Like Heroin\\", and \\"Lonely Day\\" are all frustratingly inert. From the wonderfully painful \\"Freedom! We're free!\\" of Holy Mountains, we are reduced to hearing \\"Terracotta banana\\" and Daron Malakian screaming \\"ASS!\\". The whole album has been gradually building upon itself, and these songs can best be called fillers. It truly is an anticlimax to everything that we have been treated to. In fact, as grand as the double album sounds, System of a Down have always been known for the economy. Several amazing songs from Steal this Album! just never made the cut into Toxicity (\\"Streamline\\" and \\"Bubbles\\" for example). One would have wished that System of a Down exhibited the same parsimony here. There are several songs in Mesmerize, but especially so in Hypnotize, that just did not need to be there. Instead of delivering two albums six months apart, System of a Down could have delivered one classic album, filled with all the unity and form that they wanted. It was an error of judgement in my opinion. <br /> <br />It is unfortunate that System of a Down set such high standards for themselves, because this album is still really, really good. It just does not live up to their other mesmerizing albums, \\"System of a Down\\", and especially \\"Toxicity.\\"

B000059Z8J|5.0|I've been a superhero fan all my life.  I've especially loved superheroes in films and television shows.  There was just one superhero film I'd never seen - the original superhero film, without which we would have no \\"Batman Begins\\", no \\"X-Men\\", no \\"Spider-Man\\".  I needed to see \\"Superman\\". <br /> <br />The film begins on the planet of Krypton, where Jor-El (Marlon Brando) sentences three criminals to banishment.  Jor-El is aware that Krypton is about to be destroyed, but the Kryptonian elders refuse to believe him.  Moments before the planet is destroyed, Jor-El sends his one child, Kal-El, to Earth.   <br /> <br />Kal-El's spaceship crashes in Smallville, Kansas, where he is adopted by the loving Kent family (Phyllis Thaxter and Glenn Ford).  We flash forward to Kal-El - re-named Clark Kent - in his teenage years (played by Jeff East).  After his adopted father's death, Clark travels north, where he discovers the Fortress of Solitude, an enormous ice fortress where the spirit of his deceased father, Jor-El, rests.  After conferencing with his father for a long time, Clark Kent (now played by Christopher Reeve) travels to the city of Metropolis to aid humanity. <br /> <br />It's easy to see why this film is such a classic.  It's spectacular.  Director Richard Donner crafts a well-told, adventurous story that held my attention from beginning to end.  Christopher Reeve was an absolutely perfect choice for Superman; the differences between his portrayals of Clark Kent and Superman are truly magnificent.  Gene Hackman is at his best as the cheery, maniacal supervillan Lex Luthor, who is aided by an enjoyably foolish Ned Beatty and Valerie Perrine as Mrs. Teschmacher.  Margot Kidder does a great job of showing how head-over-heels Lois Lane is for Superman.  And Marlon Brando is terrific in his nine or so minutes of screen time. <br /> <br />Another high point of the film is John Williams' fantastic score.  It's easy to hear why Williams' score is so popular amongst fansof the film.  It's everything the soundtrack to a Superman movie should be. <br /> <br />The script, by David & Leslie Newman, Robert Benton, and famous novelist Mario Puzo is, at times, epic.  It's well-written, funny, and it never lets up.  It also remains quite faithful to the comics which the film is based on.   <br /> <br />I'm mightly glad to have finally seen \\"Superman\\".  It's a fantastic film, still ranking amongst the very best superhero films nearly thirty years later.  I can hardly wait for \\"Superman Returns\\"! <br />----------------------------------------------------------- <br />THE DVD: I don't normally talk about the DVD in my reviews, but I've got to this time.  This DVD is spectacular.  Along with a bunch of great special features, the film looks amazing - brand new at times!  The Surround mix is really super, although the dialogue sounds a little dull and quiet at times.  \\"Superman\\" fans are in for a major treat!

Stalin's purpose was to punish the USA by letting Mao's troops chew up as many American soldiers as possible.  Stalin and Mao dragged out the war while Kim Il Sung begged them to stop.  Except for #4, which I think can be proved false, these are all in the \\"can't be proved\\" category.  The sources for these claims are interviews with surviving critics (or their spouses) of Mao and Stalin.  Very weak, and contradictory too. I will be on Bonnie Faulkner's KPFA (Berkeley) radio show on November 30, 2005, talking about this book. My interview may later be available on line in the KPFA archives. Aswell as the Abba sampling on the first single, there's also a Donna Summer sampling (\\"Future Lovers\\"), a song which sounds like a \\"Love At First Sight\\" remake (\\"Get Together\\"), the rumoured second (\\"Sorry\\") and third (\\"Jump\\") singles, a song about Madonna's homage (\\"I Love New York\\"), and a song called \\"Forbidden Love\\" which you will recognise the name of because it was included on Madonna's 1994 album. There's some relaxing yet shaky and danceable songs (\\"Let It Will Be\\", \\"Like It Or Not\\"), a song that explores Madonna's robotic voice (\\"How High\\"), a slice of R'n'B edge across dance (\\"Push\\") and Madge's tribute to Kallabah (\\"Isaac\\"). Simply fantastic return.

Please....though this holds up well to repeated listenings, Enya, knock our socks off on the next one...AND DON'T TAKE SO LONG THIS TIME!!

0743267478|5.0|Despite heartrending descriptions of sexual abuse, racism, poverty, homeless and much, much, more in modern India, this is an utterly enjoyable picaresque adventure that is one of the best reads of the year. In the hands of another author, the brief life story Ram Mohammad Thomas would probably be told as a simple tearjerker tragedy and the reader would be left to shake their head sorrowfully at the plight of another poor third-world soul. However, Swarup has a gimmick framework up his sleeve, and it works like a charm. Granted, one has to be willing to go along with the premise that this entire structure is based on coincidence of colossal proportions -- readers who aren't willing to suspend disbelief will probably not last more than a few chapters.<br /><br />We first meet the 18-year-old protagonist in jail, where he sits accused of defrauding the popular TV game show \\"Who Wants to Be A Billionaire?\\" (in rupees). Despite being abandoned at birth, uneducated, and left to fend for himself for most of his life, it seems Ram somehow managed to answer the show's twelve questions correctly. To all outside observers, his social standing and lack of education appear to preclude this happening legitimately. However, just as the police are about to unleash some heavy manners on him, a mysterious lawyer intervenes and takes him away. The story then unfolds question by question, as Ram tells her via flashbacks to his life just how he managed to know each answer.<br /><br />Ram's life story unfolds as a series of episodes ranging from the horrific to the merely tragicomic, and in a sense, one can view him as emblematic of India's lost children, and the book as caustic social commentary on contemporary India. Aside from being abandoned at birth, he must contend with a pedophile priest, a closeted homosexual movie star, a violent, drunken neighbor bent on incest, international espionage, child slavery, numerous thieves, a suicidal employer, and the deaths of several close friends. And yet, despite this bleak subject matter, the intrepid Ram keeps doggedly moving forward and surviving. This isn't done in a sentimental, \\"triumph of the human sprit\\", after-school special way, but in a straightforward manner that shows a confused young boy doing whatever it takes to live. And of course, the ultimate moral of the story is that those who keep their eyes and ears open in life can learn a lot about it without any books. An excellent story, well-told, and doubtless to be made into a film.friends. And yet, despite this bleak subject matter, the intrepid Ram keeps doggedly moving forward and surviving. This isn't done in a sentimental, \\"triumph of the human sprit\\", after-school special way, but in a straightforward manner that shows a confused young boy doing whatever it takes to live. And of course, the ultimate moral of the story is that those who keep their eyes and ears open in life can learn a lot about it without any books. An excellent story, well-told, and doubtless to be made into a film.
0307276902|4.0|This was a very compelling book and was difficult to put down.  For anyone wanting to understand what it's like to be an alcoholic or drug addict and a person going through recovery, this is mesmerizing.  There is a stream-of-consciousness writing style, which I didn't particularly like or dislike, but I suppose it did make the story grittier and more real. <br /> <br />As a bit of a spoiler, one of the more controversial aspects of this book is the fact that Frey completely rejects the 12 steps approach of AA.  At the treatment center, he often treats his therapists with disrespect, plays cards while important speakers talk, and nearly gets himself kicked out two times.  For someone who is close to the reality of addiction, I can imagine this account and his perspective may be troubling, as AA has undoubtedly saved untold numbers of lives.  However, I don't think Frey is arguing, as some reviewers have suggested, that AA is wrong for *everyone* - clearly he despises the program and its methodologies, but he rejects it only for himself.  I suppose he does judge others who have found solace through AA as \\"weak,\\" and throughout the book there certainly is a toughness and an arrogance to him, but I don't believe he really holds any particular grudge against these people. <br /> <br />Instead, Frey finds solace in the Tao Te Ching by Lao Tzu, in his relationship with Lilly, in the relationships he gradually builds with some of the therapists at the center, and in his realization that his addiction is not a disease but is a choice that he can control.  This was one of the more compelling passages in the book I believe, where he distinguishes between diseases such as cancer over which the individual has little choice or control, and alcoholism or addiction which, he argues, are much more so a matter of choice and control.  I'm sure many alcoholics and addicts and their families will dispute this, but I believe there is a legitimate other side here that Frey exposes. <br /> <br />Again, is this possible for everyone - could you put a glass of liquor in front of any recovering alcoholic and would they reject it as he did? - of course not.  But I didn't find him to be proseletyzing in this book, telling other people what to do - he was simply telling his *own* story.  And it is an extremely gritty story to tell (this is NOT an easy read, many disturbing passages), one that can make a person begin to understand the horrifying reality of addiction.
0307276902|5.0|This book grabbed from the first paragraph and kept me mesmorized until the very last line.  What makes it different from some of the other popular rehab books like Dry, etc. are the vivid and realistic characters Frey describes and developes throughout the book.  Frey's skillful mastery of  language to show, not tell, his state of mind makes for an honest and not always pretty read.  My bet is that when (not if) this is taken to film, the exquisitely written dental scene will replace the Dustin Hoffman Marathon Mail as the archetype dental office horror footage. It's all an extremely personal and honest account, a great book club read. Recommend it very highly.
B000006NUW|5.0|The sound is terrific-fresh, clean and crisp. Don't be too concerned with complaints about the set being in Mono-the fact is that this does not matter. What's important is NOT whether the songs are in stereo or mono, but how well the track is mixed and balanced. In the 60's, stereo mixing was mostly an afterthought, where most of the effort went into getting a well balanced mono mix for the 45 rpm market. These mono mixes may very well represent the original intentions of the artist and producers over the stereo versions. <br /> <br />The set represents how fine mono mixes can be, as good as some of the mono mixes of 60's recording pioneer Joe Meek in the UK.

B00000J7A2|5.0|Without a doubt the captain's most commercial and publicly attainable album.  This makes it the perfect place to start or to back off to when you need a break from avant gaurd.  The most prominent feature on the production is, of course, the Muddy Water, Pigpen growl of a voice that is the genius Beefheart.  His delta blues mannerisms are evident throughout the album , especially in the bluesy and semi uptempo \\"Sure Enough and Yes I Do\\"; Ry Cooder covering the slide part extremely well.  This is certanly blues, but not as we have all come to know and love it.    The ryhthm section of the Magic Band truly shine on this recording.  The bass and percussion breakdowns of \\"Zig Zag Wanderer\\" and \\"Abba Zabba\\" are absolutely phenomenal.  Proof that you don't need to show off and squese as many notes as possible into each second to sound great.  Cooder does an excellent job and certanly shows his influence as well.  The rest of the magic band pull together to make a good, straight ahead(at least for them) album.    \\"Call on Me\\" is an interesting little pop number in the style of Otis Redding.  It's one of the low points on the  album, but that's not saying much.  This fades directly into the in-your-face blues-rock romp of \\"Dropout Boogie\\".  The lines-you wanna do what-I told you what and n' what about after that-always get stuck in my head for a while.  The little instrumental dittle, ding da ding da ding, you know, that part, is pretty damn cool aswell. \\"I'm Glad\\" always reminds me of a Zappa and the Mother's song (in a good way)    The thumping-hardhitting \\"Electricity\\" is a favorite of mine.  The high pitched voice covering the lines- High voltage man kisses night to bring the light to those who need to hide their shadow deed etc.-are extremely well done.  This song starts out a couple of my favorite songs on the album, including the phycadelic \\"Yellow Brick Road\\" and the amazing \\"Abba Zabba\\".    \\"Plastic Factory\\" does remind me of Pigpen and the Dead playing electric blues like Big Boss Man or Smokestack Lightning.  I was surprised to see that others had heard this connection, but it only makes sense.  This is considered a compliment to the captain because the Dead with Pigpen were absolutely unstoppable. Beefheart is a better harmonica player and has a better style and deliverance, but Pigpen combined with the Dead certainly stand up quite well to this album on alot of occurances. \\"Grown so Ugly\\" has kind of the same effect, but it leans much more toward the Led Zeppelin side of things.  \\"Autumn's Child\\" and \\"Where There's Woman\\" are great phycadelic blues ballads that wrap up the album.    That ends the original brilliant album entiteled Safe As Milk, but I think the bonus songs truly add something to the album, especially \\"Safe as Milk\\".  Alot of these songs, or alternate versions of these songs are featured on The Mirror Man Sessions, I May Be Hungry But I Sure Ain't Weird, and Strictly Personal(I recommend these as well).  They were all originally going to be on a double album called \\"Plain Brown Wrapper\\" and would be better in this form.  These song's are the Captian's beginings into wierd phycadelia and add alot to the straight ahead feel of the original album.  They show a true progression towards Trout Mask and Lick My Decals Off, the pinnicle of beefheart and the Magic Band's work.  Overall this is the perfect album for a begginer or long time fan who needs a break from the sometimes esoteric music of later albums.

My motto is if it sounds good I will listen to no matter what anyone says my opinion is what counts mine and only mine.  I decided to write this review because I see many people either praising or completely bashing this type of music. I thought well I'll a review of the music and style not trends or biases.  Ok, first I like hardcore Warzone, Hatebreed, D.R.I., Biohazard, Sick of it All, Full Blown Chaos, Agnostic Front, Minor Threat, Blood For Blood, and other NYHC bands. Rather than me compare these bands to their influences which are very obvious let start off by saying that sadly most of the these bands do sound a lot like each other, not just a little but a LOT.  Ok Ok ok the same could be said for other metal bands but come on breakdowns(I have my own grip with this word...they are NOT called breakdowns they are called less technical solos GET IT.) are good but for the whole to be one big \\"Breakdown\\" is just really really annoying. Also, I did get into some the songs but as soon as got ready to jump out of my chair they began to actually sing the chorus I mean Taking Back Sunday and Dashboard confessional sing them, this almost made me want to punch my friend for showing this type of music It builds you up only to really really let you down. I mean Green Day's American Idiot has some singing but that is to be expected from them not this, Trust me there is a good way to sing the chorus and none of them do it effectively. Originality apparently is not a high point of these bands and well that's the sad part I mean I don't care what tours they are on or how many times they get played on MTV I really don't, just have something that people can say wow that's original or hey I think that is a good idea they used that.  These bands just lack it.  I mean there are some stand outs but not many only five come to mind Yakuza, Burnt by the Sun, Mastodon, The Black Dahlia Murder and some Darkest Hour. That's it out of seriously dozen's of bands only these five and they aren't even the most popular of the bunch, but do stand out.  KSE, Unearth(NOT TO BE CONFUESED WITH UNEARTHED), Trivium, Lamb of God, Norma Jean, and well I guess you know the rest, are not mediocre bands but they are NOT groundbreaking either.  Every Metal/Hardcore Fan knows that there is this spark this THING that a band has to have to make it truly great (If you are a MUSIC fan you know what I am talking about also) and these bands just miss it.  Then again if you are into metalcore for the fashion and the trend then Hey what ever floats your boat but don't act like you are in it for music that just makes you look childish and immature.  Oh and BTW Hardcore plus Metal are not new listen to D.R.I. and Cryptic Slaughter and tell me this stuff now a days is cutting edge(minus the singing), it just goes to show there is nothing new under the sun but remember INNOVATION is not the same as invention.  Innovation is what is lacking from these bands also. Finally, I would just like to add that music is music but for it to be truly great it has to have that THING I was talking about.  You strive to find it and you will never be disappointed.
B00082IJ08|5.0|I came here to write a review about this album, expecting to be the only one this crazy about this album. But glancing through the reviews, it seems that a LOT of people are fanatical about this album like I am. <br /> <br />I bought this album on a whim after having had the first album for so long. I probably listen to this album every other day. <br /> <br />There really, honestly isn't a bad track on it. My least favorite moments are probably the rap section of Dirty Harry, and the track \\"White Light\\". But even those are listenable, and I still find myself singing along. <br /> <br />This album sounds like Pink Floyd, if Bob Dylan were the lead singer. There are moments on this album (the end of \\"Kids with Guns\\", \\"El Manana\\" that sound like they could have been taken off Pink Floyd's \\"Meddle\\" album. <br /> <br />All in all, this is probably one of my favorite albums of all time. I don't give that title out lightly, but something about this album is just... golden.

B000069AUI|3.0|I wanted to give it 2.5 stars.  A lot of albums sound okay, but aren't really engaging enough to buy; this is one of those.  \\"Clocks\\" experienced for the very first time late at night on a decent-fidelity GM Delco car radio is undeniably memorable.  But then you play it back in your head later, and you know what? <br /> <br />It's a Bruce Hornsby and the Range.  It's Bruce Hornsby and the Range crossed with Elton John's \\"Love Lies Bleeding.\\" <br /> <br />With a little U2 thrown in for good measure. <br /> <br />And that's just Clocks.  The rest of the album is competent enough; it plays out okay enough.  A little sad-sack for what it is.  It's basically a competent, not really strong-enough-to-actually-buy album.
0141439807|5.0|Ask twenty booklovers which is their favorite work by Jane Austen, and eighteen will probably say \\"Pride and Prejudice\\".  I love \\"P&P\\" myself; I've read it umpteen zillion times and can quote whole paragraphs by heart; but as charming as it is, it's not Austen's best book.  That honor belongs to \\"Mansfield Park\\", a much deeper, more thoughtful work, written at least a decade later, at a time when rural England was beginning to feel the first effects of the Industrial Revolution; and Austen, classicist as she was, stood firm in the trenches holding onto the timeless values of stability, morality and old-fashioned uprightness.  These values are thoroughly realized in Fanny Price, and perhaps it attests to Austen's genius that the \\"heroine\\" of such a great work is such a totally exasperating individual.<br /><br />Fanny is a royal pain in the butt.  She is so irritating at times that the reader wants to slap her upside the head.  She's a loathsome little moralizing, sanctimonious goody-goody, sitting timidly in her corner passing judgments on everybody according to her own stringent, narrow-minded standards, secretly pining for her handsome cousin Edmund who, of course, is after a young woman Fanny deems unworthy of him.  She is totally humorless, an impossible killjoy, and seems to think she is the final arbitor on every moral question.  In fact, once you take away all the judging and moralizing, there doesn't seem to be much to Fanny at all.<br /><br />Austen has created some interesting characters in this book, and three of them present a problem.  The first, of course, is Fanny herself.  Then there is her horrible Aunt Norris, who is so much a caricature of evil that she seems to be a prototype for Cinderella's wicked stepmother.  In fact, many readers have compared Fanny to Cinderella, but this is not the case.  Although Fanny comes to Mansfield Park as a poor relation, she is not mistreated by anyone in the house except for Aunt Norris.  And then there is her cousin Edmund Bertram, Fanny's champion and protector, who is one of the most puzzling characters in \\"Mansfield Park\\".<br /><br />I've never seen a sympathetic character become so thoroughly unsympathetic as Edmund Bertram.  We certainly like him a lot in the beginning; he keeps Fanny from feeling lonely and neglected, and shields her from the constant badgering of their loathsome aunt.  He's warm and open-hearted where Fanny seems cold and unyielding.  When he falls in love with Mary Crawford, the reader can sense they are hopelessly mismatched, but she's a much more appealing character than Fanny.  There's not a mean or moralizing bone in her body; she's generous and kind, and if she's also shallow and materialistic, well, nobody's perfect.  But when Edmund's sister Maria drops the bomb that blows the family apart and runs away from a loveless marriage to elope with Mary's brother Henry, who has declared himself in love with Fanny, Edmund turns into a block of ice.  He not only can't understand Mary wanting to limit the damage, he decides Mary is corrupt herself for attempting to do so.  Edmund drops poor Mary like a hot potato.  From being a sympathetic and likeable character, Edmund now appears as a sanctimonious prig; unable to understand and forgive, concerned only with passing judgment.  He and Fanny are made for each other.<br /><br />The biggest problem of all with this book is the ending.  After thoroughly developing the plot and the characters, Austen all of a sudden decides to wrap it up as expeditiously as possible.  So in three chapters she dispenses with Maria's adultery and its devastating effects on both the Bertram and Crawford families, Edmund dumping Mary and marrying Fanny, Maria's banishment, Julia's elopement, and ties everything up in a neat little package.  Convenient, except that it feels hurried and contrived.  This is no way to end a great book.<br /><br />What does Mansfield Park itself finally stand for?  Like its owner, Sir Thomas Bertram, it's a bastion of stability in a rapidly changing world, rolling up the barricades against the forces that threaten it.  But Mansfield Park is flawed itself, built and maintained as it is on the hellish cruelty of West Indian slave labor,and we come to realize that both Mansfield Park, and Fanny herself, represent a last stand against the forces of a rapidly changing world that, for better or worse, will sooner or later render them obsolete.  Perhaps Jane Austen saw it coming herself, which would account for the dark undertone of the book.  It's the most profound of her six novels, and for this reader, her best book.<br /><br />Judy Lind, it's a bastion of stability in a rapidly changing world, rolling up the barricades against the forces that threaten it.  But Mansfield Park is flawed itself, built and maintained as it is on the hellish cruelty of West Indian slave labor,and we come to realize that both Mansfield Park, and Fanny herself, represent a last stand against the forces of a rapidly changing world that, for better or worse, will sooner or later render them obsolete.  Perhaps Jane Austen saw it coming herself, which would account for the dark undertone of the book.  It's the most profound of her six novels, and for this reader, her best book.<br /><br />Judy Lind

They aren't very original and don't sound too different from everything else on the radio. And yet I have all 3 of their cds and they get regular play.  First cd is really mellow and almost pure atmosphere music. 2nd cd has a lot of hits and was highly acclaimed and blah blah blah. This is the one that spawned the radio darlings Clocks and The Scientist.  But anyway, back to x&y- or should I say, the mock U2 album. I swear they must've studied every U2 guitar book they could get their hands on because on nearly every song I hear these familiar chords and think what the hell...? wait a minute..?<br /><br /> But it still works, and the songs are still good. Chris Martin's got one of the best falsettos out there and even though the lyrics are really simple and almost cheesy at times, they still get stuck in your head and you still develop a rather large soft spot for them.  They've got a knack for writing really great emotive love songs. They take the everyday and make you sing along to it. It's as if you could've said/thought of all the same things, but for some reason it wasn't validated until you heard Coldplay sing it.<br /><br />x&y sounds like they went to space and back. it's full of dynamic catchy swirling melodies...more intricate than any of their other stuff. not much is new lyrics wise, they pose all the same questions.... present all the same musings on love and life and confusion, but nevertheless it's classic coldplay and just as addictive as everything else they've put out.  I'd like to see them live someday, but their ticket prices are ridiculous and they sell out within an hour. Dammit!

0316921173|5.0|HERE'S SOME PRACTICAL KNOWLEDGE: I read \\"Infinite Jest\\" a year ago.  It took me about 3 months, on and off.  I have a friend who took a year to read it.  An honest estimate, I believe, is about 50-70 hours of your times.  I think I took about 70 hours, but I'm a slow, patient reader. Read the footnotes-they're part of the story. You'll know when you can skim them.  And a note to Mr. Wallace: Some of those run-on sentences don't work.  You lose the reader.  I forgive you, however. <br /> <br />IT'S OKAY IF YOU DON'T WANT TO READ \\"INFINITE JEST.\\"  Here's the thing--this is a great book.  A really, really great book.  But it's really long, and it's just plain hard to read.  I've heard some people rant against the \\"illiterate populace\\" who aren't patient or intelligent enough to understand \\"Infinite Jest.\\" Hogwash.  It's just really, really big, and some people have other things to worry about, things like kids, jobs, social lives, and hygiene.  I happen to be encumbered with only the job, these days, so I was prepared to dig in.   <br /> <br />IF YOU'RE GOING TO READ \\"INFINITE JEST,\\" remember, Mr. Wallace is a post-modern author.  There's no set definition of post-modern, but with respect to Mr. Wallace, it means this doesn't read like a John Grishom novel with a straight plot line or a definite beginning, middle, and end.  The New York Times wrote a nasty review about \\"Infinite Jest\\" because of this.  After initially agreeing with that review, I sat around and thought about it, and I've changed my mind.   <br /> <br />As I said, it's not an easy read, especially when you start.  Once you get in the rhythm, it gets better and better.  You'll be rolling after the first 200 pages or so, but you have to suck it up until then.   <br /> <br />AND FINALLY, THIS BOOK IS FUNNY.  And it's creative.  There are wheelchair assassins and giant hamsters, and it's set in the future where the years are bought by corporations, so you get \\"The Year of the Depends Adult Undergarment,\\" or\\"The Year of the Trial Size Dove Bar.\\" There are three brothers, one with a giant arm, one with a giant leg, and the third with an enormous head.  You'll genuinely like them all when you're done.  It's about drug and alcohol abuse, corporations, politics, and society.  There are a million small stories through this book, and they're delightful.  You can read other reviews and figure out why everyone is so mad about the ending, but if you want to read Infinite Jest, don't spoil it.  Get mad, all by yourself. <br /> <br />ONE LAST THING: you are not God-on-the-throne if you finish this book.  You are not better than everyone else.  Please stop, it's embarrassing.  But you ran the literary equivalent of a marathon, so good on you.  Like me, it might open up new avenues of literature for you, and that's a good thing, too.

1400031087|5.0|It's been a number of years since I've read a book as moving and brave as this. The book itself is simply a phenomenal accomplishment with an extraordinary range of emotion, sometimes comic and sometimes tragic -- although in the end uplifting. Frey's memoirs are harrowing, they constantly surprise us, and they are unsparing in the belief that one must take responsibility for one's life and actions. He has contempt for excuses, especially his own. He is unsparing, searching, and even angry about those who blame something or someone else for their troubles.<br /><br />The writing style is terse, direct, and perfectly tuned to the mood of the story. One device he uses throughout is repetition of phrases emphasis, perhaps conveying an addict's obsession. It also has the effect of tying it into epic oral literature such as Beowulf or the Iliad, with Frey tagging characters to phrases \\"her eyes blue Arctic eyes\\"or \\"his edge of violence, control and power\\" in the same way that Homer repeats \\"rosey-fingered\\" dawn or \\"clever\\" Odysseus. The book reads as fluidly as if it were spoken to you.<br /><br />One piece of IMPORTANT ADVICE: PLEASE DON'T read the back page before you get there! I made this mistake wondering if there was an index, and the last page tells the fate of those in the book. It's better to have this waiting for you at the end.<br /><br />On the down side there are a few incidents that don't seem to ring true (an incident with a priest in Paris is not quite plausible), and his conflicts with the AA program may also strike some as counterproductive for one in his condition. In balance this book is still a considerable accomplishment

It would have gotten a much bigger reaction from the audience. Finally while Barry's voice can become a little strained on the falsettos at times he's still great and Robin is in fantastic form here.

0060234814|4.0|Jeffrey Yip                                       Saturday, November 26, 2005 <br /> <br />A fascinating book...  <br /> <br />The book I chose to read I chose to read for this assignment is \\"The Lion, the witch, and the wardrobe\\", and the reason I chose it was that I have already read it's previous book in the series (The Magician's Nephew), therefore I chose to carry on with the series, as I find reading sequels one after another is a lot easier than reading independent books that I have no connection of. The setting of this book is mainly in an imaginary, magical, fantasy world named as Narnia. But the secondary setting (which is also link to it from reality) is an old house belonged to an old professor, which is in the heart of a country (probably England) fairly close to a railway station and a post office. The main conflict of the book is similar to the classical good-against-bad guy plot, which in this case, is our 4 main characters, a lion, and the forces of justice against the white witch, and her forces of evil. But among the story, there are also emotion, excitement, a slow reveal of the plot that can get any reader going and going, and also a little amount of horror. The protagonists of the story are 4 children: Peter, Edmund, Susan, and Lucy. And there is also a lion that plays a critical role, Aslan, which is also mentioned in the last book. The antagonist is the white witch, who causes a lot of trouble. The basic outline is that first Lucy discovers Narnia in a wardrobe, meets a friend there (a Faun). Then runs back to reality, but her friends wouldn't believe her, especially Edmund, who was a snide boy, and teased Lucy for who him believed as make-believe. And then Lucy started to feel distress, and then a day afterwards, they played hide-and-seek again. And Lucy ventured into Narnia again through the wardrobe Edmund also went, but gets really evil under taunting of the white-witch. So then afterwards, the 4 all got into Narnia, and they started to discover danger, and they then got into the whole fight by meeting the beavers, which then Edmund betrayed them and joined the white witch, then Aslan came, and fighting occurred between the white witch. And finally Edmund came back to them, and after victory, the 4 of them got crowned, and at the very end, they all returned to reality and that's it. Now if I was to compare this book with another book written by C.S. Lewis (The Magician's Nephew), I would say this book is more vivacious, exciting, and detailed. While the other book is quite similar with it's magical transition into fantasy, significant, positive changes brought by Aslan, fighting, and there's also a witch and children involved. This book is, in a way, quite similar to the movie of \\"The Wizard of Oz\\". There are also children, a witch, and magical, and unbelievable companions similar to talking animals in \\"The Lion, the witch, and the wardrobe\\" (such as the iron-man, etc.) In my opinion, the best parts of book was when Lucy first met the Faun, it's vivid description really collaborates with the cover, and when Edmund first met the white witch, as there was a lot of tensity, the beaver's home as it gives a book a warm side, and finally I think the war, as that was kind of like the major blockbuster scene in the novel. And some Chinaman peed on his rug. The picture is 24F progressive ) with French titles which is not in the Japanese version. The difference is subtle, but I would raise the flag on Criterion for more aggressive, powerful sound.<br /><br />Also, it was very delightful for me to get \\"AK\\", an acclaimed making documentary as a supplement, and \\"Image\\" which was aired about 14 Years ago on Broadcast Satellite (now those ware individually available with... well, about $70 here).  \\"AK\\" in Toho Box Set is presented in 4:3 with 60f video frame rate, while the one in Criterion supplement is 16:9 with 24F progressive picture.<br /><br />$40 is a bit steep for double-dipping, but I don't feel any regret. I can not wait for their upcoming \\"The Bad Sleep Well\\", the most (criminally) underrated Kurosawa film.
B00000K3CK|5.0|The message of this film is just timeless almost sixty years on.  I don't think I would allow less than a mature child to view this film not because the issue of Santa Claus' existence is called to question here.  Rather, the sight of adults behaving badly during what should be the most joyous and festive of holidays may be traumatic.  Whether Santa Claus exists is not the real focus here but the cynicism and commercialism of Christmas by those who should know better is.  The message is delivered subtlely by director-scriptwriter George Seaton.  Despite a happy ending this is strong stuff particularly for 1947 when Hollywood served up feel-good entertainment.  Edmund Gwenn, in one of those rare happenstances, was born to play Kris Kringle.  His mirth and good humor just envelope the screen.  Young Natalie Wood is a joy as young Susan, a child discouraged from believing in the fanciful.  Wood is just so natural and unaffected on the screen.
