B000AGTPUA|4.0|Believing in the spirit of Christmas becomes a challenge for a young boy in the charming movie \\"The Polar Express\\" based on Chris Van Allburg's children's book. On Christmas Eve the boy is invited to ride a train to the North Pole by the conductor (Tom Hanks) and a chance to discover the his power to believe in  Christmas once and for all.<br /><br />Although audiences initially gave \\"Express\\" a chilly reception the film actually more than broke even at the box office due to repeat visits from fans of the film and a vaunted IMAX presentation. While there have been complaints that the motion capture technology used here (a familiar technique used less extensively in \\"The Lord of the Rings\\" trilogy, \\"I, Robot\\" and \\"King Kong\\") giving the characters a creepy look, I found the film to be perfectly charming and no less inviting than watching any other CGI movie. While it's clear that this technique is still in its infancy (or, perhaps, in the toddler phase at this point), director Zemeckis makes good use of the technique to render characters that are believable and amazing background for the film.  \\"The Polar Express\\" is guaranteed to be a perennial at Christmas time. Tom Hanks essays a number of roles in the film which is something that could have been done without CGI (think of Peter Sellers and all the characters he played in \\"Dr. Strangelove\\" or Mike Myers in the Austin Powers movies) but the use of CGI makes the transformation into other characters a bit more believable visually.<br /><br />\\"Express\\" looks quite good on DVD. We don't see any analog artifacts (not a surprise given that it was shot digitally and rendered in a computer) nor do we see edge enhancement or other digital artifacts I've come to expect from movies shot either on film. Again, this isn't a surprise given the fact that this was transferred directly from the digital files to DVD. The colors on the train are warm and inviting while those set outside in the chilly, snow filled night has just the right frosty edge to them. The 5.1 Dolby Digital sound track sounds marvelous with crisp, clear dialogue and nice use of the surround format. The rear speakers get considerable workout with ambience and the rattle filled ride on the train enveloping us in the world of the film.<br /><br />The release of single and double disc movies is becoming more of a trend. It's clear that studios recognize that there are those who watch only the movie and have begun tailoring their DVD releases more and more for different segments of the audience. The single disc edition has just the movie and a trailer (unless you purchased the single disc edition at Best Buy--it comes with a mini-DVD that features footage from \\"You Look Familiar\\" one of the extras on the two disc edition).<br /><br />On the two disc edition you get a whole lot of extras some of which are interesting but hardly essential. \\"You Look Familiar\\" focuses on the performances of Tom Hanks and others in their multiple roles and the use of performance capture to enhance their acting for the film. We see footage of the live performance capture work show with the scene from the film which is a nice before and after comparison.<br /><br />\\"Genuine Ticket to Ride\\" features five featurettes after an introduction. \\"Performance Capture\\", \\"Virtual Camera\\", \\"Hair and Wardrobe\\", \\"Creating the North Pole\\" and \\"Music\\". At under 12 minutes it can't possible offer the depth that filmmakers might want. Nevertheless you'll learn a thing or two about the production and the obstacles, challenges and triumphs that faced the film crew.<br /><br />\\"Josh Groban at the Greek\\" features the popular singer performing the song \\"Believe\\" as well as a featurette on the creation of the song. \\"Meet the Snow Angels\\" Share the memories of cast and crew about their favorite Christmas. \\"Polar Express Challenge\\" provides an interactive game. It's not bad but kids will only want to play once or twice and forget about it once the novelty wears off. There'salso a number of bonus clips throughout the second disc that are called \\"Stocking Stuffers\\" to be discovered for those who wisely use their remote control.<br /><br />Surprisingly Warner chose not to provide much detail or in depth background on the production of the film and its CGI rendering techniques. That's too bad. While this kid friendly approach will certainly be appreciated by the film's core audience, adults like to be entertained and informed as well. Perhaps we'll see something more adult orientated in the \\"Special Special Edition\\" that will no doubt come out just in time for the Holidays next year.<br /><br />\\"The Polar Express\\" charms with its delightful performances, groundbreaking use of CGI and \\"performance capture\\". While the extras could have been more comprehensive and more filling, they aren't bad. I'd suggest sticking to the single disc edition since the movie is the real highlight and the second disc probably won't be watched more than once (if that). Zemeckis has done a terrific job translating this children's story to the screen although it does have the feeling that it is padded a bit. I'd recommend the single disc edition vs. the two disc as I didn't feel the additional extras were all they were cracked up to be. Everybody jump on board but make sure to bring some hot chocolate and a nice warm blanket as it's going to be a long but fun filled ride.off. There's also a number of bonus clips throughout the second disc that are called \\"Stocking Stuffers\\" to be discovered for those who wisely use their remote control. <br /> <br />Surprisingly Warner chose not to provide much detail or in depth background on the production of the film and its CGI rendering techniques. B000BJ7BCK|4.0|A great pop philosopher once said, \\"You may leave school but it never leaves you\\"*, nowhere is that more true than at the high school for the off-spring of superheroes Sky High literally located among the clouds. Although this superhero satire isn't quite as deft as  \\"The Incredibles\\" or even \\"Mystery Men\\" was at its best, it's an enjoyable romp that kids will laugh at and parents won't feel embarrassed to watch. Sure it may come across as a glorified Disney TV movie but what elevates the film above that are the performances of the cast. Will (Michael Angarano) is the son of the greatest superhero the world has ever known; The Commander (Kurt Russell) and Jetstream (Kelly Preston). When not fighting crime this married duo fight the war of real estate sales. When it appears that Will has no superpowers, he's worried that he'll disappoint his dad and end up just relegated to sidekick classes at his new high school Sky High. His worst fears seem a reality when in his first day at school Coach Boomer (the wonderful Bruce Campbell) drops a car on him and the best Will can do is avoid being crushed putting him in the \\"sidekick\\" category like his teacher The Commander's former sidekick Mr. Boy (Dave Foley). Now Will not only has to deal with peer pressure, the hazards of dating and razzing from the school bullies he also has to figure out a way to survive as nothing more than a glorified geek. Will discovers resources he didn't think he had when the school, his friends and his family are threatened by a seemingly unstoppable villain.<br /><br />As usual Buena Vista provides an exceptional crisp transfer. There weren't any analog defects that I could note and, truly, this transfer looks super most of the time. But like all superheroes this DVD does have its weakness-there's some minor edge enhancement noticeable in some scenes and some minor compression artifacts particularly in scenes that involved swirling mists and/or dust clouds. On the whole The Commander would be proud. The sound is equally super with remarkably crisp and clear dialogue. The surround speakers are nicely used putting you in the middle of the action.<br /><br />While it appears that this film might have some mild mannered extras, most of them are pretty good overall. \\"Breaking Down the Walls: The Stunts of `Sky High'\\" focuses on the stunt action of the film and, given that this is a fantasy film with flying superheroes and kids that shoot fire out of their hands, there's quite a few of those.  \\"Welcome to Sky High\\" is a behind-the-scenes featurette. It resembles the promotional featurette that the Disney Channel ran when the show was in theaters. It's not profound but then again neither is the movie and it does provide enough of a glimpse behind-the-scenes to satisfying most kids. We also get an alternate opening sequence along with the \\"I Melt with You\\" (a remake of the 80's hit single by the British band Modern English) music video featuring the band Bowling for Soup.<br /><br />An enjoyable film that probably would have been a Disney Channel original movie if not for the star power and visual effects involved, \\"Sky High\\" won't insult kids nor will they be demanding a sequel. Parents will enjoy some of the silly hijinks that happens in the film as well. It's worth a rental and might keep your kids occupied while you're busy wrapping those Christmas gifts.<br /><br />*Songwriter Andy Partridge \\"Playground\\" from XTC's album \\"Wasp Star\\"oud. 0262731541|1.0|Unfortunately, my copy of edition 3 fell open to page 81, in which the author compares forces from a piston engine to forces generated by living tissue. Unfortunately, this type of comparison is often completely invalid, particularly when the force is accompanied by zero motion in the direction of the force. For example, if the combustion force is replaced by a highly compressed spring, and if the crank is balanced exactly at top dead center, the spring will never \\"get tired\\" of exerting its force. In contrast, a human leg WILL get tired, even though no motion occurs. This is because chemical energy is consumed to exert the force even in the absence of motion.  <br /> <br />Unfortunately, with this single unreasoned comparison that drives to the core of bicycling science, the author has shot himself in the credibility foot, leaving all else he has to say in question.
B000ANVQ0K|5.0|Watched Titanic again.  Not only is this a masterpiece filled with visual storytelling and state of the art special effects but the story is of such consequence at the turn of this century, that it became an instant classic. What a compelling tale of the largest ship ever  to sink to the depths of the cold North Atlantic Ocean taking hundreds of precious lives in the process, mainly because of the senselessness of intelligent men risking everything to prove their prowess and their superiority. For what?    Everything that went into this film makes it truly a classic.  A simple rich-pauper young love story that grabbed hearts. The marvel of being on this great vessel and sailing with it again. The opulence, the characters, the color, the fun of it all.  Yes, we all experience the thrill and the excitement of the moments. Watching the events that lead up to that eventful brush with the iceberg. The spectacle, the horror and the loss of seeing it all die. We are left heart broken and we love it.  Then there was the song, so tenderly sung by French Canadian songbird Celine Dion. You bet we fell for it.    The single vision of writer/director James Cameron was determined to craft this epic, no matter what the cost. Reputedly $250 million US dollars. I remember a week before the film was to open, all the critics, media moguls and so many people in the entertainment industry knew, yes knew, that this was going to be the greatest flop in film history. So much so that the horrors of \\"Heavens Gate\\", the film that sunk the studio (United Artists), were revived. Titanic was a story everyone knew, everyone died, disaster films had had their fling and were no longer successful, and James Cameron was massively over budget to the point of the studios demanding back his salary. This film was a looser from the start. But the public prove them all wrong.    Thank you James Cameron for bringing this story to life like no other could. Yes, we truly lived the experience and are so much richer for it.    And yes, this is the DVD edition everyone has been waiting for, especially me.

B000001FA4|4.0|U2, even at the beginning, were always restless as artists. Having already hit an artistic peak with the preceding \\"War,\\" the band chose to look outside their relationship with Steve Lillywhite to expand their horizons. They chose Brian Eno and Daniel Lanois. Much like he did for Talking Heads, Eno brought the band to a new realization of what their sound on record could be, and the result was an album that propelled them into rock-star super-status.<br /><br />The mood on \\"The Unforgettable Fire\\" altered significantly from \\"War,\\" as the moody \\"A Sort Of Homecoming\\" found U2 switching to a subtle approach that had only been hinted at on their prior three discs. The texture to songs like \\"Wire\\" and \\"Bad\\" were obviously inspired by Eno, and these songs have since entered into U2's list of classics.<br /><br />That is not to say that Eno's influence on \\"The Unforgettable Fire\\" was a complete match. Both \\"MLK\\" and \\"Elvis Presley and America\\" found the still young band giving into a case of over-reaching. These kind of growing pains are what make \\"The Unforgettable Fire\\" one of U2's non-five-star CD's, and also leaves it as the transitional album between a pair of masterpieces, \\"War\\" and \\"Joshua Tree.\\" It gave U2 a chance to expel a burst of artiness and fans a glimpse of where the introspective \\"Joshua Tree\\" would take root. But still, any CD that contains songs as amazing as \\"Bad\\" or the radio-hit breakthrough of \\"Pride (In The Name Of Love)\\" has got to be recognized as a terrific effort.<br /><br />(Also, why has this album and the U2 catalog not been upgraded? U2 are easily one of the best and most influential bands on the planet, and their early albums deserve more than to have shoddy liner notes and a late 80's quality CD transfer.)

0553801503|1.0|To preface this, the first three books in this series are magnificent. High fantasy (whatever that means), at its best.  I think Martin is a fantastic writer and the Song of Ice and Fire series superb. His fantasy crushes Tolkien's boring, gay, and pretentious blather, and whether that's a thorned complement, I'll let you decide.<br /><br />A Feast for Crows, the fourth volume in the set, was never originally intended to exist.<br /><br />And it shows.<br /><br />Reading Storm of Swords a second time around, it's very clear Martin set all the characters and the action in a place where they would hibernate for five years and then pick up when the narrative began in the future, presumably during a terrible winter.<br /><br />What we missed we'd be told through backstory and flashback, a much more effective means of conveying what the reader needs to know than releasing hundreds and hundreds of pages of boring filler.<br /><br />And that is Feast... more like a dull and slightly painful school lunch you know is going to give you the runs later in the day.<br /><br />I was not surprised there were no surprises or real plot twists in this book. How could there be, when the narrative was meant to skip 5 years? Everything that happened was predictable and no one really went from point A to point B. Rather, they chilled at point A for so long it was almost painful to read.<br /><br />The Brienne chapters were pointless. She might have made an interesting point of view, but no. She's looking for Sansa Stark... going through lands in Westeros that aren't even on the map and most of which were never even mentioned before. The worst part is the whole redundancy of it. We as the reader know where Sansa is. There is absolutely no point to this quest in a successful, interesting story. Definitely, the Brienne chapters were like suffering through commercials... but they bore so little on the smidgen of story within the whole book, the reader could easily skip them without missing anything whatsoever.<br /><br />The Cersei and Jaime chapters seemed to roll and slam into each other like a group of unruly puppies in a kid's swimming pool. We get information driven into our head two, sometimes three times through their points of view as if we're reading a Left Behind book. Repetitive, redundant, and again, pointless, all of their overlapping stuff could have been cut without any loss.<br /><br />The worst thing is Martin seems to be repeating himself. The same descriptions (nipples on a breastplate, nipples on a woman) appear over and over again. Then in Jaime's chapters he repeats probably 20 times a sentence Tyrion told him about Cersei, splicing this into his narrative.<br /><br />I wonder if Martin subcontracted this out to a ghostwriter... it's really that bad, and that much of a departure from the other three in writing skill.<br /><br />There is some great stuff with the headsman Illyn Payne and Jaime sparring, and an interesting development with the religion of the Seven, but all in all, this book would have been much better for the series if pieces of it were included through flashbacks or backstory.<br /><br />EDIT as of 7-27-11. It's been more than five years but finally the second installment is out. And it's even worse than Feast. I'm downgrading my rating to 1 star as both books together is a heap of rubbish.emed to roll and slam into each other like a group of unruly puppies in a kid's swimming pool. We get information driven into our head two, sometimes three times through their points of view as if we're reading a Left Behind book. Repetitive, redundant, and again, pointless, all of their overlapping stuff could have been cut without any loss.    The worst thing is Martin seems to be repeating himself. The same descriptions (nipples on a breastplate, nipples on a woman) appear over and over again. Then in Jaime's chapters he repeats probably 20 times a sentence Tyrion told him about Cersei, splicing this into his narrative.    I wonder if Martin subcontracted this out to a ghostwriter... it's really that bad, and that much of a departure from the other three in writing skill.    There is some great stuff with the headsman Illyn Payne and Jaime sparring, and an interesting development with the religion of the Seven, but all in all, this book would have been much better for the series if pieces of it were included through flashbacks or backstory.    EDIT as of 7-27-11. It's been more than five years but finally the second installment is out. And it's even worse than Feast. I'm downgrading my rating to 1 star as both books together is a heap of rubbish.

It does not detract from the sound, as some might suggest. That said, I haven't given this enough listens yet to decide if I like it more than Mezmerize...Mezmerize was great and the pair of Hollywood songs at the end made that whole album worthwhile.  <br />Attack is a great album starter...it starts off heavy, goes into a different section that breaks into a typical SOAD crescendo that leads into the heaviness again...great political message, as always <br />Kill Rock N Roll has a nice upbeat drum section to start, and this is the song where I think the tag team singing is at its best...another great concept, in line with Old School Hollywood from Mezmerize <br />Hypnotize is also great with a great drum breakdown in the middle of it...this song is arranged perfectly, and works to expand SOAD's repetoire, if nothing else <br />Tentative is one of my favorite tracks. It sticks with the SOAD formula, with anti-war sentiment throughout...the heavy sections of this song are great, and the breakdown into the slower, more melodic sections are equally great...there's a great background vocal melody at about the 2 minute mark, that gives this an apocolyptic feel <br />Vicinity of Obscenity starts with some nice fast-paced rim shots, and remains solid throughout, one of the funnest songs on the album...reminds me of a more down-played version of violent pornography <br />Soldier Side seems to sum up the anti-war sentiment that the group has...it's a great song lyrically, and it showcases the vocal abilities of the singers perfectly...the breakdown at 2:10 is worth waiting for, and this just serves as a great close to a great year of SOAD music (\\"surprisingly enough\\" ends with the same guitar riff that begins Mezmerize) <br />Overall, this album may not win any new fans for SOAD (I'd suggest starting with Toxicity for new fans), but it's a great SOAD album that a fan couldn't do without  <br />(I'd give it a 5, but I reserve that for very few albums)
B000002H97|5.0|This is probably the least of Metallica's five great albums, but it sure packs in an exceptional punch. \\"Enter Sandman\\", \\"Sad but true\\", \\"holier than thou\\" and \\"Unforgiven\\" are standouts. <br /> <br />Other recommendations: <br />Metallica : Master of puppets <br />Metallica : And justice for all <br />Metallica : Ride the lightning <br />Metallica : Kill em all <br />Megadeth : Rust in peace <br />Megadeth : Countdown to extinction

0553801503|3.0|Just finished the book, and while Martin is not a bad writer by any means, this simply lacks the narrative drive of the other books in the series. <br /> <br />Violence is certainly toned down in this tome, and the biggest battles happen off-screen, but that's not the problem as political machinations have always been a big lure to Martin's books. 0307263118|5.0|Once in a while a novelist totally captures the reader with his exquisite, finely wrought language. John Banville in THE SEA, the recent winner of the Booker Prize, is just such a writer. If you are not careful, you will be so taken by the beauty of his words, that you may miss the nuances of meaning so important to fitting all the parts of his story together.<br /><br />The narrator is Max Morden, an Irishman who a year after the death of his wife, returns to a town by the sea where he spent his summers over 50 years ago and fell under the spell of the Grace family, composed of the mother, father and twins: Chloe and Myles, a strange young lad who has never spoken. In a style reminiscent of Proust, Thomas Mann, Henry James and the best of Edmund White, Banville's narrator goes from the summers in the past to the recent \\"plague year\\" of his wife's terminal illness to the present where he rents a room in the Cedars, where once the Graces lived, and is now inhabited by the mysterious Miss Vavasour, the current landlady, and her only other tenant, the Colonel.<br /><br />You can open the book to almost any page and read beautiful, poetic language. On our memories of our youth: \\"So much of life was stillness then, when we were young, or so it seems now; a biding stillness; a vigilance. We were waiting in our as yet unfashioned world, scanning the future as the boy and I had scanned each other, like soldiers in the field, watching for what was to come.\\" Or on Banville's description of the sea: \\"Down here, by the sea, there is a special quality to the silence at night. I do not know if this is my doing, I mean if this quality is something I bring to the silence of my room, and even of the whole house, or if it is a local effect, due to the salt in the air, perhaps, or the seaside climate in general.\\"<br /><br />I would have been content if this novel had just been about Morden's musings on first love, the inexactitude of memory, the taking care of and losing in death of a wife far too early, the mild sorrow of what he might have done differently-- he opines that if Bonnard, the artist whom he is attempting to write about, didn't have all the answers then neither should he: \\"Why should I demand more veracity of vision of myself than of a great and tragic artist? We did our best, Anna [his wife] and I. We forgave each other for all that we were not.\\" Many a decent writer would have let it go at that. Banville does not. In the last few pages of this small novel, he delivers at least three body blows that the reader-- at least this one-- was not prepared for. Looking back, I see that the writer does drop clues along the away about the possible ending. Read carefully or Mr. Banville will take your breath away.h of a wife far too early, the mild sorrow of what he might have done differently-- he opines that if Bonnard, the artist whom he is attempting to write about, didn't have all the answers then neither should he: \\"Why should I demand more veracity of vision of myself than of a great and tragic artist? We did our best, Anna [his wife] and I. We forgave each other for all that we were not.\\" Many a decent writer would have let it go at that. Banville does not. In the last few pages of this small novel, he delivers at least three body blows that the reader-- at least this one-- was not prepared for. Looking back, I see that the writer does drop clues along the away about the possible ending. Read carefully or Mr. Banville will take your breath away.

B0002ZDVEU|2.0|THE BOURNE IDENTITY was a fast-paced, beautifully-executed action movie filled with plenty of surprises. Unfortunately, this surprisingly unfocused sequel joins the ranks of INDIANA JONES AND THE TEMPLE OF DOOM and BACK TO THE FUTURE PART II as examples of the law of diminishing returns. In THE BOURNE SUPREMACY, amnesiac/CIA assassin Jason Bourne (Matt Damon) is once again forced out into the open when he's framed for murder. It's hardly the most original premise for a sophomore effort in a cinematic franchise, but surely it could have been told in a more coherent and better-paced fashion that what's being served up here. <br />     <br />In attempting to justify the continuance of a story that was wrapped up neatly in the first film, Bourne becomes a darker personality and, as a result, a far less likable character. Do we really care if he clears himself of a phony murder rap when we learn he's actually guilty of other crimes? This fatal misstep is compounded by aimless dialogue sequences bereft of genuine suspense and action scenes that are tossed in willy-nilly because that's what the filmmakers think the audience wants. A note to the filmmakers: What the audience wants is a thriller that doesn't try our patience or insult our sensibilities by thinking we'll accept a truckload of espionage clichs in lieu of a well-conceived screenplay.  <br />     <br />A great deal of THE BOURNE SUPREMACY is Supremely Dull, despite the chases, explosions, and gunplay. As this appears to be the second installment in a trilogy, they've got another chance to set things right. Even an assassin deserves better treatment than this. <br />

0553801503|5.0|[Slight spoiler warnings, and I'll assume you've read the first three books] <br /> <br />Ok, so it wasn't as good as the first three books, but that was because everyone's favorite characters, Dany and Tyrion, didn't make an appearance. But what was there was top notch. George R. R. Martin still knows how to write: his prose is crisp, his characters compelling, his plot twisting and unpredictable. <br /> <br />As you probably know, production and time issue kept Martin from including the full cast of characters. The book, such as it was, was about 700 or so pages without the appendices and preview for the next book. It was a bit annoying, but I'll live with it. He added Cersei as a point of view character, and I was quite pleased; we had seen her from Ned and Jaime's point of views, and it was nice to get inside her head.  <br /> <br />One critique might be that there were two subplots going on, one with the Iron Men and one on the Dorne. I say these are side plots only because they were told entirely through point of view characters that hadn't been so in the previous books. They weren't bad in and of themselves, and they do have significant connections to the overall plot, but it was annoying at first to have to withstand a flurry of new point of view characters. But stick with them, they get good. <br /> <br />Trust me, if you were engrossed by the first three books, you will continue to be. My friend complained he thought Arya got shortchanged in terms of number of chapters, but I think the balance was reasonable. Jaime and Cersei probably got the most face time, which isn't a bad thing: I love how, as the first book was mostly about the Starks, the series has devoted more and more time as it progressed to seeing things from the Lannister perspective. Jaime himself was my favorite in the book, as he continues to struggle with the loss of his hand and his father (his hand and the realm's). You'll notice the interplay between coping with each loss. <br /> <br />As usual, you get the trademark twists: just as Ned's death and then Robb's stunned you when you read them, there will be times when Martin unfolds a scheme that takes you aback. That was really what set him apart from the likes of Robert Jordan, Martin was willing to kill his characters. Perhaps there was nothing as shocking in this one as the Red Wedding, but trust me, he keeps things rolling. <br /> <br />So if you've read and loved the series thus far, you will enjoy the continuation. You might miss a character who didn't make the cut, but just think, that means double of him in the next one.

B00000I49J|5.0|JMC came out of nowhere in 1985, and rarely left my turntable.  I think I was the only junior high schooler in Houston who had ever heard them.  60s pop through a layer of distortion, led me immediately to Velvet Underground, one of their influences.  Darklands, there 2nd work, is cleaned up but contains the same classic 60s stylings.  \\"Beach boys on acid\\" may have been their tag line, but the Beach Boys should have been so lucky as to write some of these songs.   <br /> <br />JMC purposefully took riffs and lyrics straight off other records as musical allusions, before turning them sideways.  On April Skies, 'Hey honey what you trying to say' with exact chords, is from Chuck Berry.  Even Frankie Valli is not spared on side 1.  These were only inside jokes for other guitarists/music connesuirs, showing their influences, as JMC sounded truly original while paying homage to 60s pop in black leather. <br /> <br />I suspect reviewers that compare this or Psychocandy to later works, never heard JMC at that time.  Every record after this was a pale, pale shadow.  The simple chord structures and melodies here are pure genius.  Later recordings were more polished and complex, but this always seemed a crutch when this level of songwriting left them.  On Darklands, the philosphy seems to be, why say in 4 chords what you can say in 3.   <br /> <br />Everyone with a guitar learns the chords and progressions in one month of playing, that JMC relied upon for nearly every one of their classics.  So why is such timeless songwriting as this one in a million?  This was a question asked about Bob Dylan's 'All along the Watchtower', and the same can be said of JMC here.   <br /> <br />As proof to their own genius, they never wrote a single song that can sit side by side with the cuts on Darklands.
B0000046JP|5.0|I grew up listening to the version of Aranjuez played by John Williams as it was one of my father's favourite pieces of music and  became one of my own. I thought Williams version was stunning but now having listened to Aranjuez played by Paco de Lucia, Paco brings something extra to the music, an Andalucian understanding, a flamenco spirit, and such incredible technique, lightening fast fingers that melt into a blur.<br /><br />All in all, the spirit in which the music is played, in comparison makes Williams superb interpretation appear dull and robotic. This is surely how Rodrigo intended his concerto to be played.<br /><br />Paco de Lucia is an absolute genius and is to my mind without equal as the world's best guitarist. If you've never heard of Paco de Lucia before, you could do a lot worse than begin your discovery with this album.
B00082IJ08|4.0|I don't know whether to give this CD 3 stars or 5, so I'll cut the difference at 4. I admit, I'm writing this review on a whim.  I only just bought the CD yesterday, and have been listening - and puzzling over it - ever since.  I bought the first Gorillaz album when it came out, and Demon Days is much in the same mold, and yet while Gorillaz debut album was a little quirky and weird, it was mainly a quirky adventure into a new genre of music, something like techno-inspired mix of rock and hip-hop, and it was treated as so.  There was no serious subject material, nothing heavy or complicated about it, which worked, although made for a rather forgettable album.  Demon Days, on the other hand, expands on what their debut album started, building on the potential of this strange new music, and once again, Gorillaz finds themselves in unchartered territory. <br /> <br />Musically, the record is just as genious as the last one.  Their style is utterly unique and their sound, while as one reviewer said \\"an acquired taste,\\" is actually entrancing and addictive, and offers something for anybody, whether you like techno, rap, rock, or country, there is a smattering of flavors from all over the musical spectrum.  Often times, this makes for a very fun listening experience, but occasionally, it lapses into grindingly irritating repetition, or at times, something that is just down-right too weird to get into.  \\"O Green World,\\" a song that starts off with a minute long introduction of heavy basslines, techno \\"beep-bops,\\" and horror-movie like production, is a song I'm forced to skip almost every time.  On the other hand, songs like \\"Dirty Harry\\" or \\"Dare\\" sustain a very entertaining beat and off-brand production, that works, partly because they don't overdo any one technique.  \\"Feel Good Inc,\\" a song that most everyone has probably heard is, in my opinion, one of the catchiest songs on the album, and is one of the more melodically inclined cuts as well.  Sadly, however, there arenever two songs on this album that sound alike, and the closest you'll come to that \\"Feel Good\\" sound is \\"Don't Get Lost In Heaven.\\"  All in all, it takes getting used to, but it's an experience worth having. <br /> <br />Lyrically, however, is the sticking point I have a hard time getting past.  Just let me say, what on earth is going on here?  Gorillaz, while navigating new musical territory, seems to have gone in a similar direction lyrically.  That is to say, making everything they say so obtuse and strange, you have to work extra hard to wrap your mind around it.  I can't tell if they're lyrically brilliant, or simply careless.  There are times when the lyrics make a skewed, clever sort of sense, such as rapper-extraordinaire with more aliases than a graffiti artist, MF Doom's verse on \\"November Has Come,\\" a song with a lulling, floating sound.   Doom's lyrics vaguely hint at some his unrest with hip-hop now-a-days, in a parody like manner, and yet it's hard to be sure that's what he's really saying.  \\"Blew the whole spot/Like some old a** with skunk meat/These kids is too fast/Juiced off of junk treat/Who could get looser off a crunk or a funk beat?/\\"  It's very, very strange.  In fact, EVERY song on this album is very, very strange, and at times, I can't make heads or tails of WHAT ON EARTH they're saying. Take for instance \\"All Alone,\\" a mind-baffling track.  See if YOU can make sense of this.  \\"we happy or we lonesome/the long jump, the beat heart, from start to finish/ten spoons of spinach/the soul and the spillage/the cup that runneth ovah/we turn up the o-god!/\\"  Sometimes I think they're lyrics are bitingly clever because of their obscurity, and others, I have to wonder just what they were thinking while composing this album. <br />

0553801503|5.0|Before I get onto explaining why Jon Snow is almost certainly the son of Rhaegar Targaryen and Lyanna Stark (and therefore the nephew of Daenerys) here's my review...    I have never, ever been compelled to write a review of any of George R R Martins `A Song of Ice and Fire' series before because everything I have to say about those 3 books has already been said hundreds of times already. They are masterpieces. This time, however, its strange because the overwhelming impression I get from some of the reviews is that a few people almost WANT George R R Martin to fail, they want the series to become a disaster, which I dont quite understand. The comparisons with Robert Jordan are very unfair. Whereas Jordan has impressively achieved something no author has ever attempted (Hundreds and hundreds of pages of people tugging their braids, smoothing their skirts, drinking tea and frowning  for the last 7 books and losing 90% of his readership along the way) to suggest Martin is heading the same way is not even close. Martin cares alot for the quality of his work AND for his fans (Just take a look around his website [...] and you'll see what I mean) and reading this book makes you feel like as if Martin was writing more for US then himself. Why? The first 3 books didn't elaborate much on the history of the different cities and histories of the Houses, while this one does. The overall feeling you get is of a world that is more `lived in,' where you are a part of the world instead of being someone sitting on the fence and watching. I felt much more involved.    A Feast for Crows is a marvelous book from beginning to end, but splitting it in 2 has caused problems and you have to appreciate it in a different way. With the first 3 books, if you had a favourite character, say Daenerys, and her chapter ended on a cliffhanger, and you just HAD to know what happens next, but you had to read a Tyrion, or Jon, or Catelyn chapter first, then you did, but then... you just HAD to know what happens to them as well and before you know it... half the night has gone and so has half the book. Needing to know what happens to your favourite character(s) kept you reading and reading and made the first 3 such beautiful books. This time, however, seeing as most peoples favourite characters are removed, it can be a difficult read. If Jon Snow(Targaryen) or Dany or Tyrion or Bran kept you reading the last three times, then you might have a tough time here, as I did.    As some other people have said, this book has no `Plot'. This is true, but it does, however, have a lot of `Plotting,' people being cunning and manipulative, especially Cersei and House Tyrell. Another reviewer broke down the number of chapters each character has. I would suggest this, so that you can enjoy this book alot more. Read all of Cersei's chapters first, and then read all of Jaimes. Go through each character one by one, like that. The good thing about this book is that alot of the character storylines stand independent of one another and you wont get too many major spoilers this way either. No major event happens (as others have said) and you might find it easier to follow what happens in Westeros. Cersei first, then Jaime and then Sansa/Alayne and after that Brienne. After that read The Prophet/The Krakens Daughter/Iron Captain/The Drowned Man/The Reaver/ which will tell you about the events of Iron Islands. After that, read The Captain of the Guards/The Soiled Knight/Queenmaker/The Princess in the Tower.which tells you about the events in Dorne. Finally, read the Arya/Cat of the Canals chapters and then complete the book with the Samwell chapters. You'll find it easier to know whats going on everywhere this way and you might enjoy it more.    Alot of people have said that this book is in need of serious editing, and initially I agreed, but now I say to those people... `Give this another read.' The great thing about Martins books is that they are so very readable and I think if you read through A Feast for Crows a second of third time, it also enriches the first 3 books and changes your perception of some of the characters (like Ser Arys Oakheart and Ser Harys Swift). I think you should give it another chance. Also, many people have criticised Brienne's character but you need to look at her from another perspective, something I feel Martin has deliberately challenged his readers to search for. Brienne represents `True Honour,' by which I mean that she is a throwback to Martins numerous inspirations for the series. Martin loves medieval european history, of Castles and Knights, and of honour where, crucially, `My word is my bond.' Every main character, and I mean EVERY main character, has cheated, lied or broken an oath in some way or another no matter how small, or been manipulative with the exception of Brienne. Catelyn released Jaime Lannister with no permission, Robb betrayed his word and his promise to the Freys, Eddard lied to protect Sansa, thereby costing him his life, Theon Greyjoy destroyed Winterfell... too many examples to list. Even Jon Snow broke his promise to the Nights Watch when he bedded Ygritte. Ser Barristan Selmy, now protecting Dany, also lost his honour when he accepted Robert Barratheons pardon and joined his Kings Guard. For Martin, Brienne is perhaps the last of the true heroes, people who kept their word onto death and where an oath is just that: A pure promise that has to be kept, at all costs. Brienne just needs to be appreciated in a different way and I really like her.    Okay, now, this is just a theory mind you, so feel free to disprove it (although this is not a forum) but I am 99.99% certain that Jon Snow is really Jon Targaryen, the son of Rhaegar and Lyanna Stark. There is just so much evidence for it and the reason I said you should read Samwells chapters last is because there is a bit of information that almost confirms it. I always wanted to believe Jon was Eddards son by Ashara Dayne but awhile back I reada webpage which completly blew me away. If you mail me, I'll link you to it.     First, the evidence. You'll find most of it in the first eight ot nine Eddard Stark chapters in A Game of Thrones and a bit from what Cersei says in A Feast for Crows. Upon first reading AGoT, we always assume that Lyanna died because she was raped by Rhaegar. In fact, only one person says this. Robert Barratheon. Eddard NEVER says this, not once. Indeed, there is a strange line later on in the book. Robert discovers Dany is pregnant, much to his fury, and Eddard pleads with him not to kill her. There is a huge fight between them, causing Eddard to resign as the Hand. When he is alone there is this line: `Suddenly, uncomfortably, he found himself recalling Rhaegar Targaryen. \\"Fifteen years dead, yet Robert hates him as much as ever\\"' If Rhaegar raped and killed his sister, isn't it strange that Eddard is unable to hate Rhaegar the same way? Unless Rhaegar and Lyanna were lovers. (A Game of Thrones is too well written for Martin to make slip ups).    AGoT also clouds our impression of Rhaegar because of the words of Robert. However, he is far from the villain we think he is. Later on in AGoT, when Dany orders that all the women be her slaves so as to save them from being raped by the Dothraki, Ser Jorah Mormont says in a throwaway comment, `You are your brothers sister.' And in A Feast for Crows, Cersei is also thinking of Rhaegar fondly and how she wanted to be his wife. Cersei, of House Lannister who betrayed the Taragaryens, whose brother slayed the rightful king... that tells you all you need to know about how pure and respected Rhaegar must have been.    Similarly, the way AGoT is written, we have always assumed that the love between Robert and Lyanna is mutual. In fact, there is no evidence that Lyanna loves Robert as much as we're led to believe. Robert loves Lyanna like insane, still does. However, Eddard recalls a conversation with Lyanna where Lyanna discovers Robert has another illegitimate child and that he will never keep to one bed. She may certainly have had affection for him, but not much more beyond.    We also always assume that Lyanna has died some kind of brutal death, as Eddards dreams repeatedly show Lyanna in `a room that smelled of blood and roses.' But this could well have been that Lyanna has just given birth and she dies shortly shortly afterwards. After all, Tyrion Lannister's (The Imp) mother dies in childbirth and, even more bizarrely, far more bizarrely, so does Daenerys. A coincidence? Just remember, this is George R R Martin writing, not just anybody.    Eddards dreams repeatedly have Lyanna telling him, `Promise me Ned, Promise me.' The first time we are told this is when Eddard takes Robert to the crypts. Ned tells him, \\"`She wanted to come home, to rest beside Brandon and Father.' He could hear her at times, Promise me Ned, she had cried...' We always assume the promise is for Eddard to bury at Lyanna, but analyse the sentence again, does it really seem so? With a war raging, and so much bloodshed, isn't it very selfish to demand such a thing? Later, when Eddard talks to Arya, he tells her that she has Lyanna's wild nature. A contradiction, almost. Also, `Promise me Ned' is repeated far too often in AGoT. It seems like something an amateur writer would do, unless we consider the Promise is for something far deeper.     The Promise is almost surely for Eddard to protect Jon and never reveal his identity. Why? Because Robert would have undoubtedly killed Jon. He hates Rhaegar with a madness, so what chance would Jon have of surviving? Robert would have been even more furious that not only has Rhaegar `killed' the woman he loved, but also fathered a child with her, something he never did, or can. Also, Eddard thinks to himself in one of his early chapters that he has lived with his lies for 14 years: exactly the age of Jon Snow. Likewise, in the chapter where Eddard resigns as the Hand and pleads with Robert not tokill Dany, he thinks to himself: `Some secrets are safer kept hidden. Some secrets are too dangerous to share, even with those you love and trust.' Eddard also loses face in front of the other councillors when he begs Robert not to kill Dany, even at the risk of pushing Roberts anger to the max. Why do this, why even resign as the Hand, especially at this stage? After all, Eddard is investigating the death of a man who was a father to him, Lord Jon Arryn, why risk not discovering the truth of his death? And besides, if the Targaryens ARE killed, then it will prevent any future war, permanently. Unless, of course, there is a direct link between the Targaryens and the Starks.    The only thing that could seriously disprove this theory is Jon Snows appearance. He is a replica of his father, another thing Catelyn hates him for seeing as Robb, Bran and Rickon take after the Tully's but the only son that looks like the father is not even hers. Yet Martin does something in only the way he can. Later on, at Kings Landing, when Arya fights with the Septa and hides in her room, Eddard comes to her (When she shows him her sword, Needle). He talks and says, \\"`Lyanna might have carried a sword, if my lord father had allowed it. You remind me of her sometimes. You even look like her.' `Lyanna was beautiful,' said Arya, startled...\\" So Arya looks like Lyanna. And of course, who else looks like Arya? Jon Snow.     Finally, there is something else that struck me as mighty curious about the relationship between Robert and Eddard. Throughout the first 3 books, we are told how wonderful friends they were, how they loved each other, how much laughter there was in the halls of Eeyrie. So why did they only meet once again, in 14 years (when they put down Balon Greyjoys rebellion at the Iron Islands). I think its because if Jon grew up and he looked like either Rhaegar or Viserys (remember, Viserys was 8 when he fled Westeros and his face would be remembered), it would have had severe repercussions, possibly start another war. The journey from Winterfell to Kings Landing isn't so far, unless Eddard is deliberately avoiding Robert at all costs. And Eddard would certainly have protected Jon from Robert, thereby costing many lives in the North.    How does this tie in with A Feast for Crows? There is a little piece where Master Aemon speaks, towards the end, which REALLY makes you anticipate the future books and makes you wonder what is going to happen. At the end of Storm of Swords, Master Aemon and Mellisandre talk about the prophecy of `The Prince who was Promised' and she boldly states that it is Stannis. At the second to last Samwell chapter, Master Aemon says they were looking for the wrong person, that at first they thought it was Rhaegar as a comet was seen in the sky, but then Rhaegar believed it was his own son. (I have the UK Edition and its page 520. Maybe its the same in the USA version). Aegon was conceived at the same time, but so was Daenerys. A GoT tells us that Daenerys was born 3 moons after they reached the Free Cities, and then her mother died. However, Jon was also conceived around this period. Remember, Aegon must have been only a few months old when Ser Gregor Clegane killed him. So though Master Aemon says Daenerys was the fulfilment of the prophecy, it may also be Jon Snow as well.    There is also one other thing to bear in mind. Check out the appendix of AGoT and you'll see that in the House Targaryen line, all the Kings are `pure blood.' They are all from brothers and sisters marrying one another, therefore continuing the line and there has never been any record of a Targaryen marrying outside their own until Rhaegar marries Elia of Dorne. Why is this important? Because it seems that if anyone marries outside the line, the children will not survive. We saw this with Aegon and Rhaenys (Rhaegars children)... and we saw this with Daenerys child too. Khal Drogo was not of royal blood and their child was destined to die. The Dornes are not pure royal blood either, despite their titles. They were never one of the original Kings when the Targaryens landed on Westeros. But the Starks were. In ACoK, when Bran is the Crypts at the very end of the book, there is a tomb for Torrhen Stark, the King who kneeled rather then fought the Targaryens. So IF Jon is the son of Rhaegar and Lyanna Stark... well, you see where I am getting at.    Of course, this is all just one big theory but I can't help but feel George R R Martin is pointing us in this direction. What I love about his work is that me makes his readers THINK, something very few writers, fantasy or otherwise, do so successfully. And seeing as Daenerys and Jon are my two favourite characters, I'd like to think they are linked somehow. Oh, and I nearly forgot... Daenreys mother died in childbirth, and if Lyanna is his mother, so did Jon's. Also, their personalities are very similar, two young people the same age with vast responsibility on their shoulders, in charge of their own empires with very little support... Just remember, Mr Martin don't do coincidences.    If anyone is interested in knowing more about this theory, then send me an e-mail. I'll send you proper quotes and page and chapter references from all four books. I have a sort of eassy written on this topic. Thanks for reading this. [...]   If you have your own theories, then please do share as I'd love to hear. If you find this helpful, please do let me know too.

The rhythm section lays down an excellant groove with a free flowing ease. Song list is fun and they all seem to be enjoying themselves, which is what it's all about. I'd like to think we can look for more improvement in the future as the guys continue to jell.

B000005H3A|5.0|In the last year or so, I've truly come to appreciate the second great miles davis quintet: Miles, Herbie Hancock, Wayne Shorter, Ron Carter, and Tony Williams.  During that time, I've also come to appreciate early acoustic Herbie Hancock.  If it were not for records like TAKIN OFF and MAIDEN VOYAGE, I sincerely believe there never would have been great albums like E.S.P., MILES SMILES, or NEFERTITI.  TAKIN OFF really cooks. <br /> <br />TAKIN OFF is Hancock's first solo effort, and a strong one at that.  The lineup is pretty impressive with Dexter Gordon (tenor sax), Freddie Hubbard (trumpet), Butch Warren (bass), and Billy Higgins (drums).  I always thought Gordon was a much better sax player than George Coleman, who appears on MAIDEN VOYAGE, and would have liked to have seen him fill that role. <br /> <br />This record opens up with the popular 'Watermelon Man' which would appear again many years later on HEADHUNTERS, sounding completely different.  I actually consider this to be one of the weaker tracks.  Next is 'Three Bags Full' which has a beautifully phrased trumpet solo from Hubbard.  The interplay between Herbie and the Gordon/Hubbard combination reminds me at times of hearing Coltrane playing with Thelonius Monk.  Gordon also shines on this track, sounding comfortable in the setting, with a wonderful solo leading up to Herbie's moment in the sun. <br /> <br />My favorite track is 'Empty Pockets' which open up with Herbie playing the main theme followed by Gordon and Hubbard joining in a few measures later.  Every few measures or so, the time doubles and swings for a few moments.  The first soloist to follow is Hubbard over the main theme, with Gordon later on.  This tracks swings hard at times, and is one of my favorite acoustic Herbie moments.  'The Maze' is another exceptional track - Hubbard really shines here.  I have friends who criticize Hubbard as boring, and while he doesn't match up to Miles Davis or Don Cherry, he is overlooked just as much as this fine record is.   <br /> <br />The music settles down a bit with 'Driftin,' a catchy tune similar to later Hancock, like 'Cantaloupe Island' off the EMPYREAN ISLES album.  This track also has one of my favorite Dexter Gordon solos - you can hear that he listened to a lot of Trane in those days, but then again, who didn't?  The album closes out with the soothing '3am afterhours' sound of 'Alone and I.' <br /> <br />Altogether, TAKIN OFF is a much overlooked gem.  In addition to this album, I also recommend MAIDEN VOYAGE which was from a couple years later and we can hear a constantly maturing Hancock.  After hearing much of his music from this era, we begin to realize how important of an element Herbie Hancock was to the second great Miles Davis quintet.  I'll take Herbie anyday over Red Garland or Wynton Kelly!

B00005JOHI|3.0|I have read all Jane Austen writings(going beyond the six major novels and reading all her letters, unfinished works, minor work - juvenilia, etc.)and have read Jane Austen's masterpiece Pride & Prejudice many times in the past 20 years. I wonder what Jane Austen would have thought of the closing scene (no such corny provision made in the book) where Mr. Darcy plants several kisses on Mrs. Darcy while calling her Mrs. Darcy each time.  One such kiss would have been tolerable, I suppose.   <br /> <br />Moreover, Mathew McFayden's portrayal of Mr. Darcy is quite disturbing because Jane Austen did not intend Darcy to be shy or unsure of himself or wooden or awkward.  Rather, Darcy is supposed to be a little over-confident, arrogant and uncomfortable to be out of his environment and among peasants (at the beginning of the book).  Keira Knightly's acting fares no better.  She did not do justice to the most beloved character of English literature, Elizabeth Bennet who is witty, feisty, vivacious but never forward or desparate.  Nowhere in the book, she asks Darcy if he likes to dance or kissed or would have kissed Darcy's hand, etc.  In addtion, several of the main characters are miscast, notably Mr. Bennet, Mrs. Bennet, Mr. Collins, Charlotte Lucas. <br /> <br />The best, and truest, adaptation of Pride & Prejudice is still the 1995 BBC production with Jennifer Ehle and Colin Firth with excellent cast, no deviation from the witty sparkling spirit of Jane Austen, and with a perfect Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy.     <br />

B000001FSR|5.0|Possibly Waits' most unusual work.  It is a very strange mix of polka, rhumba, jazz, folk, blues, rockabilly, lounge, etc. It's pretty much impossible to describe this album in words, it needs to be listened to to be understood (if understood at all).  It is highly experimental.   His orchestration is fiercely imagined and masterfully presented.  It is one of those albums so rich, vivid, bizarre, and beautiful that you realize you were just in the hands of a genius when it finishes playing.  In my opinion it is probably the quintessential Waits album, because it shows so much of his range, perfectly capturing the humor, tragedy, poetry, and charm of his music.  <br />Temptation is one of his all-time greats in my book.   <br /> <br />It should also be noted that I believe this to be, next to Alice, his darkest album.  There's a very creepy and brooding tone throughout.  I think anyone interested in waits' catalogue ought to make this one of their first purchases.
B000002KOO|5.0|First and foremost, Jeremy Spencer does not play on this album. Although a great player, (Kiln House is his best contribution to the band) the sounds you hear were created by Kirwan and Green.  <br />I cant begin to say how fresh this album sounds, every time I put it on. While still able to bring you back to that warm 60's sound, it never sounds dated. This is FM's first serious departure from the straight blues which appeared on previous efforts thanks to, IMHO, Kirwan's presence.  <br />Just a young lad of 20 his maturity as a song writer is brilliantly evidenced in the first track \\"coming your way\\". The song changes from a groovy little number to a heavy ending, reminiscent of I want You (Shes so heavy). Only heavier and louder. From here Kirwan flawlessly moves from said number to the dreamy instrumental \\"my dream\\" and other beautifully sad songs like \\"When you say' and \\"Although the sun is shining\\".  <br />How is it possible for him to get no recognition in the annals of music history? To me its simply an indication that people simply dont know their music, and are too willing to accept the Claptons, Santanas and (insert other overrated player) as \\"the\\" guitar players.  <br />Kirwan constantly gets labelled as \\"Green's protege\\" when in fact Kirwan could keep up with Green's masterful playing as demonstrated on Fighting/Searching for Madge. As a songwriter, Kirwan tapped into music in a way that only the most talented musicians could do. He looked to the past for influece, while still incredibly ahead of his time, writing songs the likes of Cobain would write 20 years later. To write songs like he did, and play as he did, at such a young age, is a testament to his brilliance. <br />Speaking of brilliance, enough cant be said of Green's guitar playing either; not to mention his singing. If he had to leave after an album, Im glad it was this one. \\"Before the beginning\\" is one of my favourite album closers and \\"Oh well\\" has to be one of the greatest rock riffs ever written. Listen closely to Green and Kirwan interplay; these guys were meant to jam together. Page(not overrated)was hugely influenced by Green; just compare \\"Showbiz blues\\" to Zep III.  <br />Green's playing had a raw power, a really special quality that no other guitarist, save Kirwan, could harness. This album demonstrates this ability all too well.  <br />This of course could not be so without one of the best rhythm sections in music history. They are the rare breed of musician who knows when to shut up and when to speak up. Every note, every beat is exactly as it should be. Transitions are flawless, (F/S for Madge, ending of \\"coming your way\\") and this album makes them sound full, heavy and just plain ol' great! <br />Come to think of it, I believe I may have already reviewed this album(or was it Kiln House, Future Games or Bare Trees?...cant remember, but you should get these anyway) Either way, listening to this album does just that; it makes you want to tell people about it over and over again. I hope that this lineup, which is shrouded by that monster \\"Stindsay Buckinnicks\\", will earn their rightful place as the lineup representing this band's creative peak. That is to say, once Danny Kirwan left the band, they lost that sound that made this band so special, and gained two members who were so generic, so bland, so very \\"easy listening\\". Please enjoy!
B000002KIE|5.0|You can argue on and on about how much better the Clash were, or the Buzzcocks or Stiff Little Fingers or The Slits or 999 or Gang Of Four; or Black Flag, The Minutemen or Minor Threat; or the Butthole Surfers or The Flaming Lips; or Nirvana or Mudhoney.  It doesn't matter. Regardless of their \\"authenticity\\",goals, or musical ability of the Sex Pistols, Never Mind The Bollocks is THE punk rock record.  In 500 years, when some kid googles \\"punk rock\\", this record will be the first result.  The dictionary definition, plain and simple. Me and a million others never would have gotten into (or formed) these other bands if they hadn't heard this record (except maybe one by the Ramones).  If you don't get it, drink a six pack of imported beer with someone you wanna' have sex with but haven't and listen to this record/CD.  That's punk rock you're listenin' to.

B000002U9W|5.0|For a legendary band such as Pink Floyd it's usually pretty easy to pinpoint just where their legendary status comes from.  Undeniably the 1973 \\"Dark Side of The Moon\\" would probbaly be it.  But I some fans and definately a lot of critics forget the transformation that a band such as Pink Floyd had to go through to arrive at their pinnacle of musical competence.   <br />       Competence is a weak word to describe the level of musical talent that went into recording each Pink Floyd album. And the 1970 \\"Atom Heart Mother\\" is no exception.  Recorded and released in what would be a \\"middle-of-nowhere\\" stage for Pink Floyd's musical taste this album was starting mold for what would be Pink Floyd's future.   <br />        What I enjoyed most about the staring track \\"Atom Heart Mother Suite\\" was my inability to place it in any kind of genre of my own.  It was progressive, it had a choir and brass, but also some amazing guitar work.  When I finished listening to the first track I honestly felt like I had just crossed the desert.  And this was before I found out that the album was originally supposed to be a soundtrack to a Western.   <br />       The very folksy and mellow track \\"If\\" would probably be my favorite on the album.  It's a song that most people can relate to.  It's a trip with small doses of insanity.  Just enough for us to comprehend and not turn away from the song like it's some sort of foreshadowing tale of what will happen to us all.  <br />       My least favorite but still well written track on the the album, \\"Summer '68\\", has a strong contrast between its highs and lows but there's not much to say about a badly mixed track such as this.  Although it goes over well after listening to a track like \\"If\\".  \\"Fat Old Sun\\" is by far the best written track on the album.  With it's nostalgia filled lyrics and great guitar work the you can't help but love the song.  It's true the track is badly mixed also but the band's reproduction of the song live is something every Pink Floyd fan should see. <br />       To end the album the band decided on a simple track with mostly sound effects called \\"Alan's Psychadelic Breakfast\\".  Most critics have ridiculed Pink Floyd for making such a track because they found it pointless.  Well I was very satisfied by all the sound of water running and sort of coherent and delayed speech from Alan himself.  The few guitar and keyboard parts in this track was truly well done and I believe it was a great ending to an amazing album. <br />       With that \\"Atom Heart Mother\\" was released and paved the way for more progressive, socially engaging music to come from Pink Floyd.  The album is a must for any Pink Floyd fan.  It may be fair to say that it was just way too ahead of its time.
B000BTJDG2|5.0|In a little under a month (as of this writing) one of the year's best movies, \\"The Exorcism Of Emily Rose\\", will be coming out on DVD.  It's coming in two formats - the theatrical edition and the unrated edition, which presents something of a dilemna.  Normally I Always go for the full uncut version of a movie, even if it means waiting a long time, but now in the case of two movies I've seen at the theater this year (this and \\"Dark Water\\") there are unrated editions coming out of what was perfect the first time around.  My curiosity and my instincts are to go with the extended editions (\\"Underworld\\", \\"Dawn Of The Dead\\" etc. would Not have been as good with Any of the material in the Unrated Extended Editions absent), but there's a vague fear of 'why tamper with perfection' in this case?  I don't know, maybe I would have felt the same if I'd first seen \\"Underworld\\" or \\"Dawn\\" in the edited theatrical versions, although I can't think of anything that could have been cut from either of those movies that wouldn't have diminished their greatness.  Anyway, the theatrical version is what I've seen, so that's the edition I'm reviewing. <br /> <br />   First of all, if you have any qualms about not seeing this movie because of it true life connections (as opposed to \\"The Texas Chainsaw Massacre\\", which despite the hype was only Very loosely based on real events, the basis of the story having already been formulated - according to Tobe Hooper - before he ever heard of the Gein case) I'd urge you to see the movie anyway.  I admit to having had some uneasiness myself, unlike with a series such as \\"Amityville\\" which was launched with the support of the people actually involved in the real (I suppose I should say supposedly real, although I find the story credible) events.  \\"The Exorcism Of Emily Rose\\" was based on undeniably real events - whether or not you believe in the possession angle - involving real tragedy, so I did have my doubts. <br /> <br />   Suffice it to say thatthe first half hour of the movie annihilated those doubts completely, and not just because of the super quality of the movie.  I can't be specific without risking spoilers, but I'll say that \\"The Exorcism Of Emily Rose\\" proved to me that not only was it based on events where it was acceptable to make a movie out of it, but advisable. <br /> <br />   Juxtasposing the horror movie, the courtroom drama, and the 'theological/philosophical/ethical issues' movie as if it were the most natural thing on Earth, \\"The Exorcism Of Emily Rose\\" tells the tale of an exorcism gone wrong (not a spoiler; that's apparant from the first five minutes) and the ensuing criminal case charging the priest who presided over the exorcism with negligent homicide.  Told, in about equal ratios, in two timeframes - one leading from the aftermath of Emily's death through to the court case and beyond, the other from before Emily's initial possession through to her eventual death - the movie perfectly brings to life a cast of characters that it's impossible not to care deeply about (helped in no small part by the universally brilliant performances).  The battles in and out of the courtroom are heated, but ironically there are no human 'bad guys' in the movie.  The prosecuting attorney believes in his position, actually more strongly than the defending attorney does in hers, at least initially.  The 'bad guy' element is provided by what happened to the Emily Rose character.  In pursuing the route of an actual possession, few movies have ever come close to being so terrifying in their depiction of true, literal Evil.  And yet at the same time there is an abundance of brightness and inspiration in the tale.  Unbelievable suspense and some unforgettably horrifying moments mixed so fluently with the other side of the coin is in itself a great achievement, and \\"Exorcism\\" hits all the other marks with equal force: outstanding production, incredible visuals, tremendous musical score, superb character interaction, the whole range of everything you could ask for. <br /> <br />   Truly one of the greatest movies of all time, definately one of 2005's very best.

0064409422|5.0|I read the Narnia series aloud to my daughter as bedtime stories. We were reading from the boxed set of The Chronicles of Narnia, and we started with The Magician's Nephew. It is an interesting story in it's own right, and I assumed that since it is, after all, the \\"first\\" book in the series, that it should be read, well, first. Only later did I learn that The Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe was written first. A reviewer pointed out to me that reading The Magician's Nephew first robs the uninitiated reader of the wonder of seeing Narnia for the first time with the Pevensie children. While it is a nice prequel, I would recommend going back to it later, for The Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe is undeniably the jewel in the crown for The Chronicles of Narnia.<br /><br />In our current age of antiheros and self-interest, a trip to Narnia is like a balm. It is a world where honor matters and where even the greatest must sometimes sacrifice. It is a world where ordinary people can accomplish extraordinary things and where redemption is always possible. All of these are values worth instilling in our children - all the better that they can be introduced in such an entertaining format.<br /><br />For this book would never have achieved its iconic status if it were not, first and foremost, entertaining. While it certainly functions as an object lesson in morality, as well as Christian allegory, it does this without losing sight of the main goal of children's literature, to entertain children. There is magic in Narnia, but it is subtle. The slow revelation of the power of the characters builds the suspense and keeps the pages turning. The device of drawing ordinary children into an extraordinary world is as enticing here as it was in the first Harry Potter book. It allows a child to envision the events happening to herself. The characters are distinct and memorable, making it a pleasure to read aloud as well. I'm happy to report that my daughter and I went on to finish 6 of the 7, with #7 coming up later this year. All in all, a parent child experience worth sharing.<br /><br />Prior to the movie release, I wanted to read this to my son (age 6).  We purchesed the illustrated collector's edition, and I find that Pauline Baines' artwork fits the story's mood perfectly.  I think that readers will appreciate having these illustrations as the pictures in their minds eye more than the CGI animation that I have seen in the movie trailer.ish 6 of the 7, with #7 coming up later this year. B0006284JQ|1.0|The problem with Pop music, especially bubble gum pop like Spears, is that after one of her hits gets played a million time on the radio and the simple catchy melody that gets stuck in your head finally fades away, its not something you really want to hear again. In other words, music like this has no lasting power, and even if you liked it when it came out, it is already worn and out dated by now - so why try to buy it all again in a greatests hits collection? Not all Pop is this<br /><br />ephemeral, Michael Jackson and Madonna have been able to generate lasting pop songs, but Britney doesn't have the same weight and her songs lose flavor quickly, as does bubble gum after you chew on it for ten minutes or more.
B00006G8HX|4.0|Why does Star Trek III break the mold of odd-numbered Trek films being bad? <br />First off, it features Leonard Nimoy as the director. This was Nimoy's feature film directorial debut, but his familiarity with the Trek universe and with his fellow actors helped to move the picture along. Nimoy was especially familiar with the Enterprise bridge set, so he was able to set up a number of good camera angles there. Additionally, he was able to give every main and supporting character (except Chekov) a short moment to shine on their own. <br />A defining moment of the Trek franchise occurs when Kirk and McCoy steal the Enterprise. Kirk tells Scotty, Suly and Chekov that they don't have to go with him, and each man tells Kirk they're going. It's that sort of all-for-one attitude that has won Star Trek so many fans over the four decades it's been around. <br />Also, the film had its fair share of drama. Kirk's destruction of the Enterprise combined with the death of his son David make this one of the weightier entries in the Trek franchise. <br />Humor also plays a role in the film. Sulu's line of \\"Don't call me Tiny\\" remains one of the most-remembered bits of dialogue from the films. <br />More interesting tidbits: spacedock and the USS Excelsior make their debuts in this film. Both miniatures would get frequent usage both in feature films and in later Trek spinoff series. Also, the debut of the more recognized Klingon bird of prey made its mark on the franchise. That miniature would get used several times in films and TV shows up through Deep Space 9 and Voyager. James Sikking of Hills Street Blues fame also maede an appearance as Captain Styles of the Excelsior. <br />Special features abound on this DVD. Several folks discuss the realism of terraforming. Cast and crew talk about behind-the-scenes happenings. Michael and Denise Okuda provide text commentary offering further insights into the film's creation. <br />As films go, this Trek feature is one of the better entries in the franchise. The Search for Spock provides an entertaining yarn and a reasonable way for Leonard Nimoy to return to the fold.
B0000C9ZLD|3.0|I got nothing against the strokes. However if you're not paying close enough attention their albums tend to blur into one big song. Room on Fire is a good collection of songs but as an album it gets a little sterile. I hope the new album is a little more experimental.
0553801503|4.0|First off, it is difficult to judge A Feast For Crows without reference to earlier novels in the series.  This is a middle-of-the-series book, and naturally suffers in contrast to its predecessors; given that, Martin has made several bold decisions in writting this book.  How successful he is is my discussion here.   <br /> <br />Martin is at his best as a writer once again, with the characters he has chosen to write.  Others have already mentioned that some characters and plots are missing, and that this was a disappointment.  I also felt the lack, at least from a direct perspective.  This is why I subtract a star.  However, there are plenty of hints about the missing folks if you read carefully.  The result is \\"fog of war,\\" where the reader only knows as much as the central character at hand, with information from other perspectives that contrasts or completely contradicts earlier knowledge.  This might be frustrating to read sometimes, but it develops the impending sense of doom hanging over Westeros.  This is absolutely necessary for a mid-series novel. Even if big events have transpired, Martin cannot release the reader from the grip of the larger threat.  Infuriating, for we who must wait years between novels, but also delicious to savor, and very necessary to the tale at large. <br /> <br />Martin's choice of point-of-view characters is always interesting, and the addition of Cersei and Brienne are carefully selected, but nothing like a child's storybook: almost all of Martin's characters are the opposite of fairy-tale heroes, which makes their struggles all the more riveting.  This isn't just the listing of dramatic events, but the real story of the survivors of the Storm, which breathes irony into this particular title (incidentally, everyone wanted Feast to be just that, but they seem to have forgotten that a feast for CROWS is something entirely undesirable!). <br /> <br />Best of all, Martin keeps on fleshing out his world with all sorts of characters, from underjailers to wandering pilgrims to seafood hawkers in the Free Cities, and each character however small leaps vividly off the page.  This is Martin's greatest strength as a writer, and this book actually brings in new peoples, like the Braavosi bankers or Summer Island sailors, in tantalizing ways that hint at larger roles to come.  These glimpses, combined with HUGE new pieces of information being dropped into conversations (Doran Martell's final words in the book made me leap up and cheer) almost incidentally, merit a slow, thoughtful read instead of a page-turner, but A Feast for Crows was written for savoring, not for quaffing! Martin makes the very best out of the middle-of-the-series syndrome, fleshes out the story and keep the suspense flowing strong.  I am waiting with baited breath for A Dance with Dragons!
